speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what the hon. member says is essentially correct. We on the government side learned perhaps an hour ago that the hon. member for Don Valley North would not be available.
We endeavoured to see whether the debate could be brought forward to this time on Bill C-63, and unfortunately members opposite essential to that debate could not change their plans on time. I would concur in the suggestion of the hon. member.

Mr. Speaker, I normally would agree, but I am quite prepared with a speech now that would help fill in the vacuum until twelve o'clock.
I would not want to upset too many applecarts, but certainly after I made my few remarks, I am sure there
would be somebody else who could fill in the time slot until we got to twelve o'clock.

The hon. member for Annapolis Valley-Hants puts forward an interesting suggestion which I think would have some sympathy in the Chamber.
However, just so that everybody understands this, we would ordinarily be going into private members' hour. The hon. member, whose motion would be before the House, has had to advise us only a little while ago that she cannot be here.
The dilemma is this. It does not give the opportunity for any other private member to bring in his or her motion. If the government desires to go ahead with Bill C-63 at this time, it creates a situation where members who wish to speak on that bill, not expecting to be debating it until after private members' hour, are not here.
The hon. parliamentary secretary has made it clear that he agrees with the hon. member for Windsor West that under the circumstances the appropriate thing is to stand the House down until twelve o'clock.
While I certainly understand the position of the hon. member for Annapolis Valley-Hants, I think that is what we will have to do.
SUSPENSION OF SITTING

The hon. member for Don Valley North is not present to move the order as announced in today's Notice Paper. Accordingly, the order will be dropped to the bottom of the order of precedence for Private Members' Business, pursuant to Standing Order 42(2).
Thus the sitting will be suspended until twelve o'clock noon. Is that agreed?

Agreed.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Pursuant to order made Friday, May, 1, 1992, the House will now proceed to consideration of the motion of the Minister of Finance for second reading and reference to a legislative committee in the Economics envelope of Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the budget it brought down on February 25, 1992, the Conservative government announced it would eliminate, consolidate, defer or privatize 46 government agencies, corporations and commissions, which supposedly would enable the government to save $22 million per year. On March 10, 1992, Bill C-63 heralded the termination of the first six.
Bill C-63 is the instrument this government will use to implement the worst proposals in its latest budget. This bill will abolish the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, with a budget of $227,000 and nine employees; the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, with a budget of $5 million and 40 employees; the Economic Council of Canada, with a budget of $10.3 million and 118 employees; the International Centre for Ocean Development, with a budget of $13.3 million, 74 employees in Halifax and additional staff elsewhere; the Law Reform Commission of Canada, with a budget of $4.8 million and 36 employees; and the Science Council of Canada, with a budget of $3.1 million and 29 employees.
It is surprising the government felt it had no alternative but to eliminate these agencies. Why this ruthless sacrifice on the altar of privatization? Let us analyse the
Conservative strategy. Consider two recent initiatives, one that will cost at least $20 million and one that is supposed to save $22 million. The first one, the prosperity initiative, has a budget of $15 million and several million dollars more for consultants and advertising.
This initiative, announced last fall with a great deal of hoopla, is intended as a response to the challenges facing Canada in its search for competitiveness. So far, it has been an excuse for the government to delay action and rehash initiatives already announced and studies already released. Canadians will also be treated to a lot of expensive advertising, meetings and discussions, but very little action will be taken to deal with pressing economic problems.
The second initiative, Bill C-63 before the House today, is a so-called austerity measure. However, the savings will be very meagre, considering the federal government's total budget of $161 billion. In the budget, the government announced it will wind down or merge 46 government agencies and in the process save $22 million. Bill C-63 deals with only six of these agencies. To eliminate some of the best sources of research in Canada at a time when they are so badly needed is a waste of precious knowledge and expertise and means abandoning major research.
Those are policies we owe to Brian Mulroney and his Conservative friends.
As we know, the Economic Council is nearly 30 years old. The Law Reform Commission is over 20 and the Science Council of Canada is over 25. These agencies have acquired great credibility and a wealth of talent over the years. They are independent, free from shortterm political priorities, able to take the long view and give sound advice and suggestions on directions for future policies.

Bill C-63 indicates that the government has lost sight of the values of these agencies. Perhaps it has become too sensitive to critical evaluations of its actions. In my view, this bill is bad for democracy. I wish to quote Arthur Drache in the Financial Post of March 5, 1992, in reference to the decision to close the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada and the Law Reform Commission:
May 4, 1992

Removing these institutions from the Canadian landscape is a method of decreasing dissent and criticism of government policies. The net result will be that those who challenge policy have been deprived of quasi-official platforms and would be marginalized. Governments were forced to respond to reports by the councils and commissions, and those reports served as a focal point for Canadians who want policy considered in a context other than solving the immediate crisis or making political brownie points.
Mr. Speaker, I want to examine what we will lose through Bill C-63.
The Economic Council of Canada: The final report under the council's name on education and training was released last Wednesday, examining the sorry situation of our educational system. This important research calls out for action, the trademark as we know of the Economic Council of Canada.
Arthur Drache described the council in the Financial Post of March 5 as follows:
The only credible challenger to the Department of Finance on economic policy issues. Finance piously killed one of its main tormentors in the name of saving money and then suggested that the same research will be handled in the private sector and in the universities. Everybody in Ottawa knows what scant attention Finance pays to those sources when it comes to economic planning and forecasting.
What does this tell us about the Tory government? Once again I would suggest that it does not like to hear criticism. The fate of the Economic Council of Canada reports in progress on health care, human resources, management, the impact of governments in competitiveness, the adaptation of firms in trading relationships with the Pacific Rim is not yet certain. Government departments or universities may attempt to complete the research but this represents a potentially damaging transfer of a project in mid-stream.
The Financial Post of April 15, 1992 reports that the Department of Finance will provide $3.4 million to finish projects still in progress when the council closes its doors on June 30. Two and a half million dollars has already been spent on these reports.
How does this fit with the savings these measures are supposed to give us? If the Economic Council of Canada was not doing a good job or relevant work, why is the government handing out millions of dollars to have its work completed by others?
Government Orders
The government pretends that the private sector and universities can take up this work but they cannot undertake, in my view, in-depth and long-term research the way the council could.
The Ottawa Citizen conducted a survey of university academics and economists with research organizations, brokerage firms and banks, and reported March 10,1992, that:
Few, if any, do the in-depth, long-term research the council did.
For example, universities and research institutes surveyed say they do
not have the resources to undertake multi-year research projects.
It seems to me ludicrous that this government would expect universities to pick up where the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada will leave off, the same government that is slowly starving universities of federal funding and that has a pitiful record in supporting research and development at these institutions.
The Science Council of Canada: Closed.
The Science Council of Canada has provided exceptional foresight and policy options. In 1971, the council recommended recycling, including separating household waste. Energy efficiency was studied in 1977. In 1967, the council recommended the establishment of the Canadian Space Agency which was finally opened in 1989.
What will happen to the projects the council has just begun on the prosperity and economic competitiveness campaign?
John Polyani, the Nobel Prize winning chemist quoted in the Ottawa Citizen of March 8, 1992, has this to say about the decision to close the Science Council of Canada: "One gets the impression that the ship of state is large and expensive and we have to do something about it so we have cut off the rudder".
How will the work of the Science Council of Canada be replaced? The budget papers suggest that other advisory bodies have emerged since the council's establishment such as the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology chaired by no one else than the Prime Minister of Canada and including some cabinet ministers. Mr. Speaker, I put it to you humbly, what kind of rudder is this?

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
How does this highly independent board intend to substitute for the in-depth and unbiased research of the Science Council of Canada? Does the board intend to take over the plans for an annual report card on the state of Canadian science?
This year the council was to publish its first report on the state of Canadian science. This ongoing annual report was to give an idea of our progress, valuable information in helping us compete. Why does the government not want a report card on the state of science in Canada? Is it concerned that such a report card will show its lack of commitment to providing more?
In part III of the estimates for 1992-93, the Department of Industry, Science and Technology, looking at the science co-ordination and leadership which is in charge of the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology, we see that the budget has been increased by almost $4 million from $24.8 million to $28.2 million. What is this budget increase for? At the same time, the government could not find $3.1 million for the Science Council, an arms length council, a council we trusted, a council that gave us good advice.
The Law Reform Commission. The Ottawa Citizen of March 11 reports that Canada will join Zimbabwe and Bangladesh as the only Commonwealth countries without independent law reform bodies. This government is leading us proudly to Third World status.
The Law Reform Commission has published 32 reports, 64 working papers and 76 studies. These have been influential. In 1990, it was found that these papers had been cited in 211 reported Canadian court cases, including 39 Supreme Court decisions.
The commission is scrambling to publish working papers still in progress. At the beginning of May, working paper 65 will be released. If the commission does not run out of time before the boom is lowered in June, working paper 66 and the 20th annual report will be released.
One of the casualties of this commission will be a report on multiculturalism. The president of the Canadian Bar Commission has written to the Prime Minister to protest this decision. As the president, JJ. Cam notes, it may be that the government considered the commission "too independent".
Last December the commission presented its last report to Parliament: "Aboriginal Peoples and Criminal Justice".
How will the work of the Law Reform Commission be replaced? The budget papers say the Department of Justice will do part of it and the rest will be handed to researchers in universities and elsewhere.
How much money will be spent by the department to replace this work? The Department of Justice has increased its litigation budget from $59 million in 1990-91 to $89.5 million in 1992-93, an increase of $30 million in two years and civil litigation as part of that budget from $22.6 million to $34 million in two years, an increase of $11 million. But there was not enough money to cover the $4.8 million required to keep the Law Reform Commission going. I will ask the minister to explain that decision.
The Department of Justice intends to hire 70 lawyers this year. I would like to know what these people are going to do.
The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security was established in 1984 in order to provide an independent view of Canadian foreign policy and various international issues. In the Ottawa Citizen of March 7, 1992, we read that the latest annual review of the institute was critical of some of the government's decisions, including its delay in providing aid to the former Soviet Union. It is noted the institute was just reaching maturity, acquiring an international reputation, and proving itself an important source of sound information and intelligent judgment.
Thanks to this government that source will soon no longer be there. This seems ill-timed when the world has entered a time of unprecedented uncertainty as countries break up, boundaries are withdrawn, and millions of people adapt to startlingly different and new realities.
External Affairs, we are told, will take over the work of the institute. Once again it is painfully clear we will go from having an independent assessment and review to one fettered by the short-term view and political needs of the government.
It is questionable when money will actually be saved through the closing of the institute. Lulfilment of contracts and obligations, a 10-year lease, severance packages, are likely to put off savings for at least two years.
May 4, 1992

The International Centre for Ocean Development, the decision to close this centre which helped developing countries manage their ocean resources, is particularly surprising given the Tories' claim to be working to protect the environment. Is this decision in line with the government's green plan? What does this say to other countries about our commitment to taking care of fisheries, particularly in the context of the turmoil off the coast of Newfoundland? It is all very puzzling.
CIDA, we are told, is to take over the projects of the centre. Has this been budgeted for?

The only way to understand these cuts is to see them as concessions to win over the right wing and get dissatisfied Reform Party members to vote Conservative in the next election. Abolishing the agencies mentioned in this bill will cost over 300 jobs and add to unemployment in the national capital region. Cuts to the public sector in the national capital region have disastrous effects on the private sector. In a report entitled "Otta-wa-Carleton Economy: Looking Ahead", the Conference Board of Canada estimates that for every job lost in the federal government, one and a half jobs are lost in other sectors in Ottawa.
Most of the people affected by Bill C-63 are highly skilled. Their expertise will be lost just when we need it most to revive our economy and strengthen our education system so that Canada and Canadians can be better prepared to face the 21st century. .

This bill shows the Tories' distaste for democracy. They obviously do not like Canadians having information which shows the flaws of their own policies.
As David Crane of The Toronto Star notes, this government has been slowly cutting off the sources of information and independent research for years. I give Statistics Canada as an example. The reports were made self-financing by the government. This ultimately meant important studies became very expensive placing them out of the reach of many. Demand fell, not surprisingly, enabling the Tories to claim there was no longer a need to publish these reports.
Government Orders
In closing, I would like to quote Mr. Drache in the Financial Post, March 5, 1992: "Confident governments give us boards, agencies, and commissions which would act as policy counterweights. It is a feeble and fearful government which takes these away in the name of saving a pittance in terms of government spending. Depriving Canadians of information, alternative views on public issues from credible sources and the ability to clarify our rights is short-sighted in the extreme, but then as many feel about the budget its vision is targeted no further than the next election."
What will the legacy of this bill be? The irreplaceable loss of valuable research, acquired and accumulated knowledge and expertise, a more solid vision of the action that must be taken for the future in return for minimal savings, destruction for nothing more than political expediency.
I avoided speaking about the cutting of the Court Challenges Program which in my view is also a serious mistake by this government. It has cut a program which was one of the most efficient and effective programs, not very costly, less than $2 million a year. It gave minorities, all minorities, be they linguistic or others, the right to go to court and have their rights clarified. This government cut that program which cost less than 10 cents a year per Canadian. I find that absolutely unbelievable.
Bill C-63 falls within the Tory philosophy of cut, cut, cut. This bill is bad legislation. It should be withdrawn. I will not support this legislation. I will vote no when the vote is called.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the big difference today between the Liberal Party and the Progressive Conservative Party in this country is that the Liberal Party looks back and the Progressive Conservative Party looks ahead.
The philosophy which has been one of the guiding principles of this government during its eight or nine years in office is that the responsibility of the government is to look to the present and the future and not to the past. Part of that philosophy has been one of privatization.

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
My hon. friend in his remarks referred to the sacrifice of these institutions on the altar of privatization.
It is our view that the purpose of government is to provide necessary services to the citizens and not to employ them. It seems that it is the policy of my hon. friends opposite that the purpose of government is to employ people.
We believe the purpose of the government is to create a climate in which the private sector can grow, develop and employ people. The economic policies of this government are targeted and, indeed, notwithstanding the current recession would appear to be working in that direction.
When we look at institutions which were created 30,40 or 50 years ago, if they continue to serve a public policy process and a public policy role and if they are providing services that are not being provided by other institutions in Canadian society, then obviously, it is part of the government's policy to maintain them.
If as in the cases of the Economic Council of Canada or the Science Council of Canada for example, since their inception other institutions have come along providing the same kind of valuable research or providing the fora in which such research can take place, then we ask the question: Why is the government at the cost of the taxpayer maintaining administrative bureaucracies to do things that can be done by private institutes or, indeed, are being done in the universities?
That is what this piece of legislation is about. This piece of legislation has absolutely nothing to do with what my hon. friend indicated, that this government is removing these institutions because of criticism of their reports.
Over the years there have been many excellent reports done by the Law Reform Commission, the Science Council, the Economic Council and other institutions whose discontinuance was announced in the budget.
Some of the reports have been very supportive of the government. For example, the Economic Council of Canada strongly endorsed the free trade agreement. Its wisdom, it seems to me was not so well recognized then by my hon. friends opposite as it seems to be today.
If there are not going to be sources of independent, effective research provided for the benefit of government in this country as a result of the removal of these institutions, then I can assure my hon. friend and his colleagues opposite that these institutions would not have been removed by the budget that was brought down last February and passed by this House.
It is very important that we understand this bill is here for two reasons. First, it is because the Canadian taxpayers have said to the government: "Streamline government and make it more efficient". That is what this is all about. Second, this type of research is, indeed, available through the excellent work being done in our universities and various other institutes across the country.
Perhaps my hon. friend might care to comment.
Mir. Gauthier: Mr. Speaker, we have a serious disagreement. I can tell. I always thought that, yes, we were moving forward, but one must know where one is coming from to be able to orient himself or herself in a proper manner. There is nothing wrong with looking back and saying that we had some good reports and good work done. In my view, it is very useful.
As far as the principle of privatization is concerned, the principle of this bill that is at second reading stage is to shut down, to abolish 46 agencies.
The Liberal Party of Canada is not opposed to privatization. We do not support government policies that call for the elimination of organizations which, in our view, continue to serve the public policy purpose. We see this commitment to divestiture on the part of the Conservative government as a feeble attempt to silence its many critics. I thought I had made it clear in my speech that what this government cannot stand is for somebody to oppose or to criticize it. As I said, it is a feeble attempt to silence its many critics. I really believe that. In particular, the Reform Party is threatening every one of them in their seats. That is the reality. That is the truth. They know it.
When I hear the member saying to me in this House that these cuts, these closures are to more efficiently and effectively spend public funds, I ask the member: On a budget of $161 billion, the savings will be $22 million. There are 300 jobs at hand here. Scientists, top-notch
May 4, 1992

lawyers, people who were trained, who had the expertise and the knowledge, where are they going to go?
The movement naturally will be to the United States. We may lose an awful lot of good intellectual talents that we have over the years trained to do research for us so that we would have arm's length from the government's policy, arm's length from its interference some objective reports to Canadians about certain directions we were taking, about certain policy options that were available, about very difficult problems that we are all facing on the environment.
The Science Council was the first to point out to us that we had to do a couple of things essentially to this planet to maintain it. We have to look after garbage and do it quickly, otherwise we are going to kill the planet. The Science Council did that 20 years ago. We are just starting today to take note of that very good recommendation made to us several years ago.
Yes, it is true that these things were in days gone by but there are still some things to be done today. I hope the member would reflect on it and change his opinion.

Mr. Speaker, my colleague from Ottawa-Vanier referred in his speech to the latest report of the Economic Council of Canada, concerning education and occupational training in Canada.
Could the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier tell me whether he agrees with what many have said to the effect that there is nothing new in that report, that the Economic Council of Canada did not do exhaustive research before publishing it but only compiled data-at least those I checked-that were two or three years old and were published by the provinces, which are responsible for education, of course? Well, that is a statement and obviously I do not deny that there is a problem. But is using the Economic Council of Canada with what it costs taxpayers to produce a report that was already produced by provincial authorities not a waste of money? The Economic Council and several other organizations no longer have a reason to exist, since the provinces have within their jurisdiction organizations that can do the work very well, instead of duplicating such organizations.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am glad to see that the hon. member for Argenteuil-Papineau reads Le Devoir. Lise Bissonnette wrote an editorial in which she criticized the Economic Council's report. It is good to have public discussion. Yes, people must talk about problems from time to time. We think that education is a national problem, but it is true that it is in provincial jurisdiction.
Government Orders
Yes, the report-and I read it-contained much that I already knew, since I spent 12 years of my life in the field of education. I know that there are problems; we all know that there are problems. We must find solutions.
As Ms. Bissonnette commented in Le Devoir last Friday, I believe that perhaps we should tiy new approaches to deal with the drop-out problem, which now affects 35 per cent of our young people. I will not argue about the value of the report with the hon. member. My point is that this report may have helped Canadians become aware of and understand an area that is so vital to a country: education. If it helps us solve the problem, it is worth the effort and the expense.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to have this opportunity to make some comment in regard to Bill C-63, to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies. It relates to the measures that were contained in the February 1992 budget.
As members will recall, that budget announced there would be the elimination, consolidation, deferral or privatization of a total of 46 government agencies, boards, commissions, corporations and advisory bodies. The reason for that is abundantly clear to most Canadians. Over the years government has proliferated to the point where it is infiltrating virtually every area of life and is choking the ability of taxpayers to be able to respond.
In times past-perhaps we should call them Liberal times-there was a tendency to respond to every possible request, every demand from the public, every special interest group, every perceived need. Consequently over the years there was an enormous proliferation of these various organizations and bodies, in excess of 400 of them, more than 200 boards, tribunals, councils and advisory bodies.

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
Over time the ability of the public to continue to support these agencies and advisory bodies has, I believe, waned. Indeed the enthusiasm has virtually disappeared. Over time public needs have evolved and changed as well. As a result of the process, the overlapping in the mandates has to be looked at and has to be dealt with, given our national debt and the obligation to find the money with which to service that debt, to pay the interest on that accumulated debt.
It is not surprising that the government in its budget undertook to reduce the number of agencies, boards, commissions and advisory bodies that it maintains. The Minister of Finance has indicated there are five basic principles that are involved in the decision-making process to that end.
First, we are eliminating waste resulting from overlap and duplication within the government. Second, we are eliminating waste that results from duplication with the private sector. Third, we are strengthening particular sectors by consolidating related organizations and their mandates. Fourth, we are simply postponing some desirable initiatives that simply cannot be afforded at this point in time. Finally, we are going to continue to privatize commercial operations that no longer serve the purposes of public policy.
This particular bill speaks of the dissolution or termination of six government organizations. They are the Science Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Economic Council of Canada, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Law Reform Commission and the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. The bill deals with these six organizations because their dissolution or termination does not require substantial amendments to other existing legislation.
The remaining organizations that were mentioned in the February budget will be dealt with through the medium of other legislation as expeditiously as possible.
I want to expand a little bit on the rationale in dealing with the decision in regard to the Science Council of Canada. In doing so, I want to acknowledge the valuable contribution that the Science Council has made to the formulation of government science and technology policies and programs. Over the years its insightful studies and reports have provided all Canadians with an important perspective on Canada's scientific and technological resources, requirements and potential. Indeed it has helped us to identify and address our weaknesses and to recognize and capitalize upon our strengths. Perhaps most significantly it has served to foster greater public awareness of science and technology and on how they truly impact upon all of our lives.
The work of the Science Council could best be described as visionary. In a number of areas it was way ahead of its time in terms of the forecasts it made and the actions it recommended. In fields such as environmental conservation, innovation in cold climates, advanced manufacturing and science teaching, the work of the Science Council gave a leg up, so to speak, in dealing with what would one day become vital issues.
It maintains its tradition of probing into a diverse range of emerging issues. For example, some of its recent projects have dealt with sustainable agriculture, science and technology for the social and economic development of northern communities, science, technology and constitutional change, and genetics and health care.
It is not a matter of the Science Council having to fulfil its mandate. The Science Council is not being punished for doing a poor job or, as some misguided individuals have suggested, for providing government with advice that government does not want to hear.
Put simply, the government's decision to wind up the Science Council is based upon a reality that cannot be ignored: changing times. These days one would be hard pressed to come up with a subject that is discussed, debated and theorized upon as often and as extensively as the subject of Canadian competitiveness.
By Canadian competitiveness I mean the ability of our industries to keep pace with rapid technological change and to compete successfully in the international marketplace.
A competitive Canada translates into a prosperous Canada, a Canada which is able to maintain and enhance its well earned reputation as the world's most caring and compassionate society. It also means opportunities especially for our young people, opportunities for world-class education and training and opportunities for exciting and rewarding careers.
May 4, 1992

Responding to the competitive challenge is a shared responsibility. Government at all levels, industry, labour, academia, all the key players in our economy have a role to play. The primary role of government is to provide the leadership, the policy and program support which will foster a climate conducive to competitiveness, to innovation and to growth.
To that end back in November 1984 this government introduced the plan for economic renewal. It is an agenda that has guided our economic policy to this day. It is comprised of a number of wide-ranging strategies that taken together help to create the environment in which business can grow and prosper.
Deficit control has been a major element. Government operations now run in the black. Only the interest on the national debt contributes to the deficit today. I think it is important in this context to revisit history briefly, because in the year 1982-83 the Government of Canada ran its operations in the red to the tune of $11 billion. That is excluding the requirement to pay interest on the national debt. It is just the day-to-day operations of government, the transfers to the provinces, and paying for the programs. The government of the day was in the hole to the tune of $11 billion.
In the year 1983-84 it was in the hole to the tune of $14 billion and in 1984-85, $16 billion. That was the peak and it is no accident that it coincided with the last year of the Trudeau government.
Since that time enormous progress has been made to the point where, excluding the requirements of the interest on the debt, the Government of Canada is today operating all of the programs, providing all of the services, and in fact has a surplus of $12 billion left over at the end of the day.
Obviously that $12 billion unfortunately is not enough to pay the interest on the accumulated debt, but we are indeed light years ahead of where we would have been had the free-spending regime of the past continued.
The deficit back in 1984-85 consumed over 8 per cent of the Gross Domestic Product of Canada. Today it has been cut in half to the point where it is slightly over 4 per cent.
How was this done? It is hardly any magic and there is no secret about it. It has been done the only way possible: by reducing expenditures and by increasing revenues. It means tax increases and it means spending
Government Orders
and program cuts. There are no other ways. There is no magic out there.
The opposition parties within this Chamber continue to refuse to recognize that reality. It is interesting because provincial counterparts certainly in Saskatchewan and Ontario, now that they are in charge, have come to realize that there is a reality out there, that governments have no money other than that which they get from the people of the country, from the taxpayer, that there is no other source, and that every program that comes forward has to be paid for.
The reason we have the problems we have today in terms of debt and the requirement to pay interest on that debt is because of past overspending, the failure of successive governments back in the 1970s and early 1980s to present taxpayers with a bill for the programs at the time.
Instead they pursued what I may refer to as the Liberal way, which was to say: "We will have all these programs and institutions, no problem. We will have them but we will not pay for them. We will just have our kids pay for them in the future some time. Perhaps the grandchildren will pay for them, but we will not bother people today so that we can continue to get re-elected".
There has been a sea of change in the attitudes of Canadians. Most Canadians now understand loud and clear the source of the funds which governments use to operate. The source of the funds is the pocketbooks of Canadians. Canadians are saying that they are tired of the tax burden. They want to see some action on the part of governments in terms of downsizing, in terms of eliminating waste, duplication and so on. This budget and this bill do respond to those concerns.
Those management initiatives announced back in the fall of 1984 include the privatization of over 20 Crown corporations and the downsizing of the Public Service. There is something in the order of 90,000 fewer employees in the Public Service at this point in time.
We have introduced regulatory reform and major changes to regulations governing transportation, energy and communications industries. Our intellectual property laws have been modernized and strengthened. We established Investment Canada which encourages foreign investment and will be of net benefit to Canada. We brought forward tax reform including the elimination of

the federal sales tax on manufacturing. Every step of the way these measures were opposed by members opposite, opposed for the sake of opposition. There was never an alternative, simply criticism.
When the goods and services tax came forward, was there any suggestion of an alternative other than to continue to borrow, borrow, borrow? The answer was none. There was no alternative put forward by opposition parties, and to this day there is no alternative out there because there are no alternatives.
The path forward to the 21st century has also included the free trade agreement with the United States. It has included the ongoing GATT negotiations. It now expands its horizons to include a North American free trade agreement.
Taken together the measures of the government's plan for economic renewal have provided for an environment in which the private sector can be the engine of growth for the Canadian economy. We have come a long way in building a more prosperous and competitive Canada, but there is still a lot more to do.
On February 25 the Minister of Finance outlined the government's fiscal priorities, the next step in our long-term plan for sustained growth. At the root of this budget as has consistently been the case with the government was the commitment to streamlining government and improving the service provided to Canadians, in other words to ensure that our own house is in order. This has involved taking a long, hard look at the departments and agencies of the federal government in order to save overhead and to focus resources.
In the case of the Science Council of Canada it became apparent that the changing times dictated that the council be wound up. As I said at the outset the council has played a useful role since its creation back in 1966 in providing advice to government and in stimulating research and debate on issues of science policy.
However recent years have seen changes both inside and outside government. Today numerous sources of independent advice on science and technology exist. We have the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology, for example. The NABST is a broadly representative body of prominent Canadians chaired by the Prime Minister. Since its inception in 1986 the board has provided valuable advice which has had a significant
impact on government policies and programs. The national network of centres of excellence and the Canada scholarships Program are concrete examples of government decisions based on any of the ST advice.
Not only does the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology provide scientific and technological policy advice at the national level, but many of the provinces have created science advisory bodies that provide advice on a regional and provincial basis that relates to their specific situations.
In addition to the NABST, some other sources of independent scientific and technological advice include the National Research Council, the Council of Science and Technology Ministers, the National Forum of Science and Technology Advisory Councils, the National Biotechnology Advisory Committee and the National Advisory Panel on Advanced Industrial Materials.
At the same time, many private groups also provide independent advice, including the C. D. Howe Research Institute, the Business Council on National Issues, the Royal Society of Canada, and the university community through such groups as the Canadian Federation of Biological Sciences.
The federal government believes that science and technology policy advice should come from as diverse a group as possible. That is why it is encouraging science and technology policy analysis in the higher education sector and in the private sector, as well as in governmental and quasi-govemmental institutions.
Finally, with respect to the role of the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology, like the Science Council of Canada the NABST is an independent advisory board. The government does not direct the issues the board examines, nor does it determine the conclusion the board reaches.
The government, therefore, has a combination of many sources of advice with discretion to determine which sources may be appropriate on particular issues. The government is committed to ensuring that the current work of the Science Council of Canada will be phased out in an orderly manner. Ongoing work will be transferred to the responsible federal departments or agencies. In the next few months before the closure date, the council will publish a number of final reports, including the studies undertaken through its extensive R
May 4, 1992

and D strategy project. That project examined a number of vital industry sectors, reviewed the R and D challenges it faced, and presented a number of strategies and recommendations for enhancing competitiveness.
It is appropriate, I believe, that we salute the many dedicated men and women who have contributed to the high quality work of the Science Council of Canada over the past number of years and recognize the talent and commitment of these individuals because they have done a great deal to advance science policy in Canada. But at the end of the day the fact remains that there are, as indicated, other agencies, other departments, private sector, universities, and so on.
There is also the compelling problem of finances. This particular bill speaks to some six of 46 government agencies, boards, commissions and advisory bodies that will be dissolved or eliminated as a result of the February 25 budget. The result will be some 500 fewer people on the government payroll, 160 fewer appointments, a saving of $22 million for this year, up to $71 million five years from now, something in the order of $300 million over five years.
There is no question that the agencies involved here have done good work, and there is no question that other agencies do good work. It is never easy to do away with certain agencies, commissions and so on. If they had no raison d'etre, no purpose, hopefully they never would have been created in the first place. However, I do believe that it is instructive to note a proliferation of these various agencies and Crown corporations and various governmental bodies over the past 25 or 30 years, to note that government has tripled and quadrupled in size, that the bureaucracy has grown to such incredibly large proportions, to note the burden on Canadians in terms of taxation to the point where Canadians in the middle income area of $50,000 are seeing more than half of their earnings taxed back between federal and provincial governments. Of course, there is a third level of government out there as well, municipal. All levels, municipal, provincial and federal, I believe have to bear in mind at this point in time that there is only one source of funding and that is the tax revenues that are gathered

from those same people, those same Canadians. Whether it is their municipal government presenting them with a tax bill, whether it is their provincial government presenting them with a bill or indeed whether it is this federal level of government, the fact remains that there is a crushing burden out there.
I believe firmly that the steps that have been instituted over the past seven and a half years have stabilized the situation. We see that the deficit this year in fact is half of what it was in 1984-85 relative to the economy. Indeed, by the latter years in the 1990s we will through hard work, through eliminating various programs, have reached the point where there will be no further requirement to borrow. That will be a happy day for all Canadians.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am rising today to oppose Bill C-63 strongly. It has the purpose of dissolving or ending six extremely valuable organizations: the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law Reform Commission, and the Science Council of Canada.
The government has said that it is necessary to eliminate these six organizations and in fact another 40 as well because it is necessary to save money and also because the purpose for which the organizations have been set up is either no longer required or is more effectively carried out in other hands.
Liberals certainly do not oppose examining the usefulness or the necessity for government bodies and organizations like those mentioned in this bill, in fact the entire group of 46, but we say that the government has not made a case for the elimination of the six organizations listed in this Bill C-63. On the contrary, the more it struggles to try to justify what it is doing in this bill, the less convincing and the less credible it is.
First the government says that it is necessary to eliminate these organizations in order to save money. We are talking about some $22 million out of a total government expenditure of $160 billion. There are those who would argue, and I can see this point of view, that if expenditure is not justified even if it is a relatively small amount then it should not be carried out. But is this the
Government Orders
case with respect to the six organizations listed in this bill?
It is interesting that after this measure was first announced there was a unanimous view outside government that this was a mistake. All those people who were aware of the work of these organizations or who became aware of them rose, almost with one voice, to say that these bodies were carrying out useful and necessary work and that it was a serious error to eliminate them.
It is interesting that the government is supposedly concerned with the private sector but when it comes to the future of these six organizations it is refusing to listen to the private sector. It says that the six councils listed in this bill are performing valuable work and that there is no solid alternative in the private sector where this work can be carried out if these organizations are ended.
It may well be there are organizations in the private sector that would carry on some of this work, but to do so they would require funds. If that is the case then I ask: Where is the saving? In other cases when the government has been pressed to explain who would carry out projects under way of great value like the project on competitiveness that is being carried out by the Economic Council of Canada at the request of the Prime Minister himself, or the study into the economics of health care also being carried out by the Economic Council of Canada, the government has said: "We will have this work carried out inside other government departments". Again I ask: Where is the saving?
In other cases the government has said: "We will have to provide funding to allow these agencies to complete this work or have it contracted out". Again I ask: Where is the saving? When it comes to saving money the government has not made a case at all as to why, if the government wanted to save $20 million, the elimination of these six organizations, these six agencies, is the place to get this saving.
What about the so-called prosperity initiative? This travelling road show is going around seeking people's views on how to make the country more competitive, an exercise which all those concerned, even those participating in the meetings, say is unnecessary. We already have the answers. What we need is not more talk but action.

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
There is $20 million right there to be saved by not carrying out this so-called prosperity initiative which will not even have a final report for close to another two years. What we need is action now on improving our competitiveness as a nation. We have many of the answers already from reports of bodies like the Economic Council and the Science Council which this government wants to eliminate.
If the government wants to save money in the area of $20 million, why not eliminate $20 million and more from this government's bloated advertising budget? Instead of doing that, this government is getting involved in other useless advertising campaigns like the one that will be under way soon to try and explain the unexplainable, to try and make a case which cannot be made that the free trade deal has been helping Canada. There is an area of saving.
I want to mention another one which I already raised in this House. In the estimates for last year this government has provided $2.5 million to pay for the construction and operation of a museum of humour in Montreal and there is another $3.5 million in this year's estimates to go to the same project. Is this a worthwhile expense?
When I raised this in the House during Question Period, I said perhaps there is a case for the museum of humour because it could be a place to display the whole array of this government's broken promises and the whole array of this government's failures. But would such a display cause people to laugh or to cry? Either way this is an area of questionable expenditure in the minds of many.
If the government wanted to save money in the amount it claims it will save from cancelling the six organizations in this bill and the other 40, I might say in passing there are a number in the group of 40 that may well be justified in being eliminated. However, if the government wanted to save money I think it would be easier to find better alternatives than the six worthwhile, proven organizations listed in Bill C-63.
As I have said, if the government carries on the work in house it will still spend the money that way, just as if it has had the work carried on in universities or private think-tanks. The money will have to be provided in any event.
If that is the case somebody may ask as to why we need these particular organizations. The answer is simple. It is because the government has not made a case that we no longer need the kind of arm's length, independent, complete, wide-ranging, in-depth work that these organizations, particularly the Science Council and the Economic Council, have proven they can do in the interests of the well-being of the Canadian economy and Canadian society as a whole.
I challenge them to show any modem developed country that does not have the equivalent of these organizations operating under public auspices today. I include governments like the Republican Government of the United States or the Conservative Government of Britain.
We are eliminating the kinds of bodies that governments of even more right-wing persuasion than the current Conservative government, if that is possible, have decided they need. There is a lot to be said for the kind of work-arm's length from government, independent, in-depth and wide-ranging carried out by the Science Council and the Economic Council of Canada.
This does not mean that their work is beyond criticism or questioning. That is something that will always happen in a modem democratic society. That does not mean that their work is not of value and necessity.
Proof of what I am saying is the fact that one of the current major projects of the Economic Council of Canada is the study on competitiveness which the council was asked to do by the Prime Minister. He did not say he wants to have this done but there are already other bodies in government that can do it. He did not say there are think-tanks out there in the private sector that can do it. He turned to the Economic Council.
In cancelling the life of the Economic Council of Canada, he could well be saying that he really did not have the commitment to improve competitiveness that he claimed to have when he made that assignment. Perhaps it is clear that in cancelling the Economic Council in the current budget, the government operated in a foolish, mindless way, typical of so much else it does under the guise of governing this country.
May 4, 1992

The troubling thing here, in addition to the concerns I have raised, is a concern raised by many, not just in this House but in the private sector, that the real reason for cancelling the six organizations listed in this bill is that the government does not want to have the sources of potential criticism these organizations represent. If that is the case, what does this government have to fear? If it has a commitment to its own ideas, if it has a conviction that these ideas are correct, what does it have to fear?
If it has support for its ideas and policies on the part of the public, the people of this country, what does it have to fear? The cancellation of these organizations says a lot about the lack of inner belief and commitment that many in this government must have. It says a lot about the closed-mindedness and narrowness that all too many in this government must have. If this were not the case, this bill would not be before us today.
On the one hand, in its budget and in speeches of ministers, this government talks about the need to make this economy more competitive and about the need to advance the technological level of our country, to build on the best of science and technology. On the other hand, and at the same time through this bill it strikes down the very agencies with a proven record of research, information and advice needed in the past and no less needed today and in the future to help us all achieve the progress and development we need when it comes to the level of the economy, technology, science and development.
Surely this bill indicates how this government cannot possibly have the commitment it should on behalf of Canadians to improving the level of the Canadian economy and of our basic level of science and research and development.
We have this bill before us. I could also talk about what this measure shows about the lack of concern about Canada's place in a safe and peaceful world when it wants to cancel the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
This bill shows the lack of commitment of this government to updating the legal system when, in this bill, it wants to cancel the Law Reform Commission. We will be one of the few countries in the Commonwealth, perhaps one of the few developed countries in the world, without an independent law reform body. It does not say much for what this government really believes in when it comes to law reform.
Government Orders
To sum up, this government has not made a case on either financial or public policy grounds for the elimination of the six organizations mentioned in this bill. All it has done is bring about an almost unanimous response from the private sector, in which this government is supposed to believe, that these organizations continue to have a necessary role and they should be continued and supported by this government.
In view of the failure of this government to make a case for what it wants to do in this bill, I have to conclude by calling on this House to reject this bill, and instead enable the six organizations listed in it to continue to have an effective and useful life in the interests of all Canadians.

CUPS was bom in 1984 as a result of a very significant and unique all-party consultation. Let me refer the House to some remarks made in 1985.
Let me quote the present Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, the former Prime Minister and former Secretary of State for External Affairs. In introducing amendments to the bill in 1985 the process of creation, and this is recorded on page 6510 of Hansard of September 11, 1985, he said:
The creation of this institute was a stellar and an outstanding example of co-operation among all the parties of the House, respected and supported by public opinion in the country, to establish in Canada along the lines of institutes established and operating effectively elsewhere in the world a Canadian institute for international peace and security.
The bill that set up CUPS and has continued until this day, and which will effectively be eliminated by Bill C-63 that is before the House today, set out as the purposes of the institute: "To increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relating to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective with a particular emphasis on arms control, disarmament, defence and conflict resolution; and to: (a) to foster, fund and direct and conduct research on matters relating to international peace and security; (b) promote scholarship in matters relating to international peace and security; (c) study and propose ideas and policies for the enhancement of international peace and security; (d) collect and disseminate information on and encourage public discussion of issues of international peace and security.
The institute that was established has had an enviable record under the leadership first of Geoffrey Pearson and later of Bernard Wood. The institute did not always please everyone. It often entered into areas of public debate and discussion which irritated or frustrated one side or another in the debate. No one ever challenged the integrity or quality of the work done by the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security throughout its years of existence. That was because its founding board, the leadership and its successive boards carefully and patiently built up a team of which Canada can be justly proud. That team, over a period of time, has served this country remarkably well.
What is intriguing is that in making the decision to eliminate CUPS, the government left the announcement, not to the Prime Minister and not to the Secretary of State for External Affairs, who is responsible for it, but to the Minister of Finance in a budget. When the leadership of CHPS came before the Standing Committee on External Affairs and International Trade it became clear that the Minister of Finance made not one effort to discover what it was that CUPS was doing or had done for Canada. No one in the senior leadership of CUPS had ever talked to the Minister of Finance about what it was doing. There was no consultation with CUPS from the Secretary of State for External Affairs about its future, and none, of course, from the Prime Minister of Canada who, in my view, given the particular terms of the legislation, had a special responsibility to this House and to the Canadian people for CUPS.
CUPS was set up by this Parliament in a veiy special way. In order to preserve its independence, the act provided that the executive director and the board were not simply to be appointed by the Prime Minister or the Governor in Council on the advice of the Prime Minister, but rather through a process of consultation with the leaders of the opposition parties in the House and, in respect of the board, with a long list of Canadian organizations.
CnPS, in other words, was a unique product of a kind of parliamentary consultation which the Canadian people would dearly love to see on a whole range of public issues. It came at the end of the tenure of the former Prime Minister, Pierre Trudeau, and represented a consultation both in committee and in the House that led to this remarkable institution and thus to the quality of the work that it did.
Its demise came about without consultation with any other members of the House and certainly not with the parties in opposition that helped create it. It was done without consultation with the institute itself. It was done without consultation with the people of Canada. Its demise is a travesty on the trust which this Parliament had placed in the Prime Minister and in the cabinet of this country.
Let there be no mistake, this move to terminate the Canadian Institute of International Peace and Security will have a very negative effect on Canada's capacity to deal with the complex issues that now face the world and face Canada with the end of the cold war. It will also do damage to Canada's prestige overseas.
May 4, 1992

I have here copies of letters that were sent in many cases to the Standing Committee on National Defence or to external affairs from around the world expressing shock and dismay at this decision. The Thomas J. Watson Junior Institute of International Studies calls it "an ill-considered and myopic decision"; Time magazine: "I would urge you to reconsider plans to cut off the institute's funding at a time when Canada's foreign policy is not only an important phase of transition but also too often overshadowed by domestic concern". That was from Time magazine, which says it found CUPS to be one of the most important and useful agencies in the world.
The Naval Officers Association of Canada and many Canadian groups, including Project Ploughshares and others, have spoken about this. Harvard University and Peter Jennings of ABC News have written saying, that this is a tragic decision. The Guardian has written, the National Institute of Research and Advancement in Japan has written.
To close, let me quote from a particularly important letter in the sense of its representation of other letters. It is addressed to the clerk and members of the Standing Committee on National Defence and Veterans Affairs, March 8 from Michael C. Hudson, of Georgetown University:
I am writing to express my astonishment and dismay at the Government's announced intention to close the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
As a specialist on Middle Eastern affairs, I have been privileged to be associated with the CUPS project on Lebanon. I follow Lebanon very carefully, and I can say without reservation that the CUPS project was the most thorough and fruitful collective study of this divided country that has been undertaken since the Lebanese crisis began in 1979.
This decision is a travesty. I call on the government to withdraw it.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, under the rules we now have for this debate on C-63, 10 minutes can go by very quickly. I am very glad I have some notes to try to get to the two points and the two agencies in Bill C-63 which give me the most concern.
Other members, including the member for Victoria, talked about the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security which is being dissolved by this bill. It struck me rather passing strange that no one has ever mentioned the International Institute for Human Rights
Government Orders
of which the former leader of the NDP is the head. I guess in the cost cutting procedures of the government, it decided to leave that alone.
Frankly, most of the arguments made for the human rights institute perhaps should have been made for the peace institute.
Before I come to the two main agencies that give me the most concern, the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada, I want to comment briefly on another agency in Bill C-63 that is being cancelled, namely, ICOD, the International Centre for Ocean Development.
From Atlantic Canada, it is absolutely passing strange that ICOD, the international ocean agency for developing expertise and knowledge of our oceans and to help the Third World in developing its oceans, with all the problems that we have in oceans and with pollution, in a cost-cutting measure in which the dollars saved are minuscule, we are cutting out and gutting the heart, soul and the very body of the ICOD agency which was centred in Halifax and was doing good work around the world.
I am going to zero in on the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council. It is a rather interesting coincidence that the Economic Council of Canada last week released a report on education and training in Canada, "A Lot to Learn". It is a scathing objective indictment of the educational system in Canada and how it prepares students for the employment market. It suggested certain recommendations.
While the government on the one hand claims that it is supporting standards of education and wants more students and better on-the-job training, on the other hand it is slicing and cutting out the Economic Council which in effect gave a valuable critique.
I would suggest in a humble way that if anyone has a lot to learn about education, it really is the government for what it has done to the Economic Council which in its last report gave very good advice as to the sorry state of the whole educational system here in Canada.
Bill C-63 is an attack on think-tanks as represented by the Economic Council and the Science Council of Canada. Basically, I cannot support this bill. I am glad I can stand here as an independent member and not follow any party line in supporting this bill, admitting full well that there are many of the agencies mentioned in

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
the budget which had to be streamlined or cut down and some eliminated, but not the Economic Council of Canada and certainly, I do not believe the Science Council of Canada.
I am against Bill C-63 for three fundamental reasons. First, the government says it is going to save a lot of money. Other members have already dramatized that of the total $22 million in the 46 agencies that are going to be cut, $11 million would have gone to the Economic Council of Canada. I would suggest that was money well spent to give objective, independent advice to any government, not just this government. This is what I want to come to because I know time is very short. I cannot repeat all the ways the government has wasted money and spent money. Other members have touched upon that.
Certainly, I cannot accept the fact that $11 million for the Economic Council with all the other millions this government has spent, be it on the Spicer commission, the royal commission on electoral reform, the royal commission on reproductive technology which has already spent over $20 million, et cetera, et cetera, that there was not enough money for an objective economic think-tank to help Canada on its road.
As other members have said, every other western country in the world has an economic, independent think-tank, independent of private enterprise, independent of government, independent of labour and trying to combine them both to give some advice to government to lead it into the new world. That is certainly not a backward step to try to maintain something that had a proven track record.
I am going to skip very quickly over my notes in view of the short time. I have the most interesting quote of all that I want to give before we wind up and give some of the history of the Economic Council of Canada.
The second point I am against Bill C-63 is that independent think-tanks, as far as I am concerned, have a very constructive role to play in a liberal democracy. I call this a liberal democracy. Sometimes I used to be very, very nervous to call this a liberal democracy. But it is a liberal democracy or a social democratic democracy
and a conservative democracy, but it is a democracy and it is very important.
An interesting thing, at this time when every essence of national unity is under stress and strain and is being frayed, is that one of the fundamental national institutions that has been an experience of this country and has helped this country for some 30 years, the Economic Council of Canada, is being gutted and dissolved.
I advise my former colleagues on the other side that the public feels uncomfortable when the government on one hand says some good rhetoric, does some good things, and on the other hand gives a negative zap and contradicts it by what it does. It thinks the left hand does not see what the right hand is doing.
We have national institutions which have done well for Canada, the Economic Council and the Science Council, and they are being gutted at a time when we need every type of strength in our national institutions that we can have. We do not have it in this bill.
Other members have mentioned this. I guess sometimes the think-tanks bring in advice that governments do not like. That happened under the Liberal government, it happened under the Conservative government, and it will happen under any government if the think-tanks stay. I cannot dwell too long on that because time is of the essence with a 10-minute moratorium in this procedural rule we have here today.
The third reason I am against Bill C-63 is something I wish government members would pay attention to because this recognition of the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council, but especially the Economic Council, is part of the former history of the party that is presently in power, the Conservative Party.
I go back many years but there is someone before me who goes even further. It was interesting in preparing for these brief moments here in this is very fundamental debate. I am glad we got rid of the procedural fracas the other day.
The member from Scarborough brought up the point so that we can have more members participate in this debate. It is good to have some discussion which we cannot have now because there are some differences among the parties. In another election people cannot say
May 4, 1992

because there is not a Tory member that could have run in the last election and got elected if he or she had come out and said they were going to slice the Economic Council or the Science Council of Canada or some of the other agencies.
In conclusion, I want to go back to some real history which means some very poignant memories for me. As far back as 1962 the then Minister of Finance in the Diefenbaker government, a man called George Nowlan, foresaw the necessity of independent think-tanks to provide government with advice on the economy. On November 27, 1962, he introduced a resolution for the creation of a national economic development board which was the predecessor of the Economic Council of Canada.
I want to quote Hansard of that day at page 2075 when he justified a board that in effect became the Economic Council. He said:
I am sure my hon. friends opposite who have had experience in government recognize this fact -ministers and their advisers within the government service are very often not able to find the time in which to take an over-all look at our economic prospects and possibilities. They are responsible for departmental administration and for the problems of their departments. Fortunately we have many well qualified and expert economic advisers, economists and civil servants generally in the government employ. I know of no country which is more fortunately blessed than we are in that connection. But in almost every case, these people, these men, these women, are responsible for administrative problems, for day to day decisions within their own departments and looking after those matters, and looking after them adequately as well as they do, they do not have the time in which to look over the whole broad horizon of the national problems which even of today, let alone those which might arise tomorrow or five years or ten years from now.
That they have to decide on.
I cannot do anything better than to conclude my remarks on this short abbreviated 10-minute interjection that the House rules allow to try and get some sense of history to the present government party who in effect were responsible for the initial inception and creation of the Economic Council by the debate in the 1960s and to recant and not support this part of the bill and vote against it.

I had the opportunity and privilege of sitting in the House when his father was a very constructive member of the House of Commons from British Columbia. Between the two of us, with an aisle between us and also a little ideology, is the sea to sea that makes Canada the great country it is. I do not want to trespass in the extension of time. I have sat here all morning and I am glad to have finally had a chance to speak because I was afraid I was going to get lost in the post-Question Period sweepstakes and have to sit here until 10 p.m. or even later tonight.
I appreciate that the member for South Shore has been running this for the government. He is a good friend of mine and an ex-teacher.
