There are a couple of parts of this bill that I am not too upset with. Some of those agencies had to go by the boards.
In conclusion, I do not wish to repeat myself completely and there are other quotes I could give. There is much I have left out of the notes. I was blessed with a speech that had more notes today in a constrained way. It helped me get closer to the time limit than I usually do. Perhaps I must follow that precedent even at my late stage in life to try and have a more refined speech. I really like to speak off the cuff. It gets you into trouble but also makes you speak from the heart. You do not need notes for the head if you speak from the heart.
Without getting too heavy, I know the government has problems with money. We all know we have to cut deficits. This debate is not going to change a thing. The government has the majority and undoubtedly, Bill C-63 will become law in time, depending on the legislative committee and what it does with it.

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
You can talk about the institute for peace. Yes, we need peace. You can talk about the institute for human relations of which Ed Broadbent presently is president and chairman. We need human relations. Someone has to make decisions and there were some decisions to cut it.
This country is under stress and strain and national institutions are really becoming rare. This bill comes in and because of budget papers eliminates the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada. The government admits full well that the science advisory board, chaired by the Prime Minister, has some very able participants and people. This is no replacement and substitute for an institution of some 20 years. The Economic Council of Canada has some 30 years and has given good objective advice to all governments.
I wish the debate could change some of the honest individual opinions that members have regardless of party line because the government is trying so hard. Many people honoured Joe Clark, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, on Saturday night for his 20 years of very constructive public service. He is now trying his greatest challenge to bring together a constitutional package. That is very commendable and very positive.
In conclusion, Mr. Speaker, you are a very thoughtful person in that chair. You grace it with dignity and you grace it with common sense. You and I know that you cannot have rhetorical homilies about national unity on one side and by other specific bills chop up some of the national institutions. It just does not wash. That is part of the problem confronting the present government.
I wish and hope the Prime Minister keeps getting out into the hinterland and going to those parts of the country that are very compatible to visiting heads of state and prime ministers because they do not see them all the time. They are naturally warm, pleasant and polite, as they should be. I hope that he keeps going and gets buoyed up by a positive reception because in conclusion,
I do not think there would be anything better than when we get our constitutional package put together in some form. It is going to be a changed Canada and I am prepared to admit that.
The greatest present Canadians could have on this 125th birthday, after we get that constitutional package together, is to let us make sure we have an election to separate the wheat from the chaff and find out who is really in touch with the people.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise on the serious matter raised in Bill C-63.
I would like to commend my colleague from Annapolis Valley on his very interesting remarks.
When the member spoke about what his father said in 1962,1 am sure that he was struck by the fact, as I was, that it was exactly 30 years ago. What did we try to do in the 1960s, the 1970s and 1980s? We tried, as a society, to respond to the information age. We tried to make sure that we were educated and that there was competition of different ideas being circulated in our country.
I can tell you, as a former university teacher, that one of the most difficult things to do in this country is teach Canadians about Canada. There are not enough sources of information. The book publishing industry is contrary to having a healthy market for books about Canadian topics.
The major research publications, the monthlies, the quarterlies and the annuals are all run in a North American context. For these reasons it is not always easy to find out in a current way, in a well-researched way, what issues are facing our society.
One would search through libraries for government documents, and more often than not, would come across the Science Council of Canada, the Economic Council of Canada. One would see their annual reports, their special reports, and would realize that here is not just a sole researcher working in isolation, but here is a research team that has had access to good budgets, to colleagues, and has been able to travel around and talk with people and communicate. There is a product of some very, very good research.
The Canadian scientific community and the social science community are marked by individual researchers working on their own. This is in part caused by the nature of our country and it is also caused by the infrastructure of the research community. It is very difficult for people to collaborate with the seriousness that the Economic
May 4, 1992

Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada provided.
In a democratic society we worry about many different fronts. We worry about, particularly in the economy, the issue of monopolies and oligarchies. We also worry in the world of ideas, the competition of ideas. How do we find out what is happening, and how do we communicate our ideas to other people?
The Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada provided us with non-governmental information. We were not dependent upon the department which has, by definition, an organizational and political agenda, which is totally legitimate but nevertheless is their own. We were not dependent upon a research facility paid for by a particular group, which is healthy but limited.
We depended upon these arm's length organizations providing good information. We have asked them to criticize the most fundamental institutions in our country. One speaker referred to the fact that last week we heard from the Economic Council-unfortunately it was its last gasp-talking about the education system.
As politicians federally, provincially and municipally, we have to come to grips with the fact that by almost every international dimension we are failing our young people.
You will never find a department standing up and saying it failed. You would never find a minister of the Crown standing up and saying he failed. You will have politicians blaming each other, the province blaming the school-board, the school-board blaming the province, the province turning to the feds.
We all know the scenarios but it takes an independent voice to say: "Listen all you men and women in public life. These young people are illiterate. They are not able to learn math and science. They do not know the history of the country. We are not able to compete internationally. Do something".
By pulling that voice out of the country's politics, you are in turn saying that it was not important to be told that. How can any politician, after talking to constituents in the last few weeks, not think it is important to talk about education and not have some objective measurements out there? He does not have somebody he can trust through the funding process to do good work. He
tells you something and then you turn around and say: "We do not want to hear from you any more. That information is too hard".
Science policy, again since the 1960s, is supposed to be front and centre to our economic development strategy. We are supposed to use science to create wealth, to apply knowledge to industries, to find the most recent and current research, to generate support for individual researchers working in isolated situations across this country, to point out to the general public where new and exciting activities are taking place, whether they be in space policy, health policy or in the abstract work of mathematicians.

speechtext: Order please. It being two o'clock p.m., the House will now proceed to statements by members, pursuant to Standing Order 31.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to draw the attention of the House to a new federal program announced by Forestry Canada as part of the green plan. I am referring to Tree Plant Canada, a major initiative to promote the greening of our environment and combat the greenhouse effect that is threatening our planet. The program will encourage tree planting by community groups across the country.
We are talking about a real partnership that will bring together municipalities, the public and private sectors and private citizens, to plant over 325 million trees over the next six years. Tree Plant Canada is a joint effort that concerns us all. It is also a program that will have a positive impact on future generations.

Mr. Speaker, this morning 75 students lined up at the student employment centre in Mississauga to find that only eight job opportunities were posted.
That is one job for every nine students.

May 4, 1992
A summer of frustration and unemployment now awaits many of these students who will also have to struggle through yet another hike in tuition this September.
In recent years, this government has compounded the hardships facing students by slashing transfers for postsecondary education and by slapping a surtax on student loans.
I call upon the government to reverse its repressive policies and begin supporting students by restoring post-secondary transfers to levels where Canada's youth will not have to mortgage the future to get a modem education.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday hundreds of people in Windsor marched on behalf of Bosnia-Hercegovina.
Like other Canadians they have been devastated by the destruction and killing taking place there. But for these people in Windsor there was the searing extra pain of knowing that their relatives and friends were the victims of the continuing violence.
I marched with these men and women in Windsor and I want to bring their message to the House of Commons. The killing must stop in Bosnia-Hercegovina. There must be peace.
Canada has recognized the new republic. We must do more. We must work for justice and peace there. We must provide emergency supplies. Canada must pressure Yugoslavia as strongly as possible to stop the violence. We must pressure both the United Nations and the United States to safeguard this new democratic country that is now suffering so sadly.

Mr. Speaker, the worst fears of our city and region were confirmed on Friday with the news of the death of Kristen Dawn French.
Kristen was a bright outgoing student at Holy Cross High in St. Catharines whose death has brought a very
dark cloud over the entire region. Feelings ranging from sorrow and fear to outrage have enveloped the area. Young women are angered and frightened because they feel they cannot walk anywhere by themselves for fear they could be the next victim.
Kristen's death has brought into focus yet again that all our energies must continue to be directed toward ensuring a safe society for our citizens.
Violence and particularly violence against women cannot continue. We must deal with the causes and effects of this violence.
I join with the other members of the House, Mr. Speaker, in sending our sympathy and that of my family to the French family at this most difficult time.

Mr. Speaker, unemployment in Canada has reached critical proportions. The unemployment rate today for our country is 11.1 per cent. In my province of Nova Scotia the unemployment rate is 13.3 per cent. Unacceptable.
But the unemployment rate among youth in our country is at the alarming rate of 18.7 per cent.
Things have never been this bleak since the depression. The unwillingness of this government to tackle the problem of unemployment is due to its single-minded war on inflation and it will cost us dearly in the future.
A whole generation of youth, future academics, scientists, and labourers will have been denied the opportunity to contribute to the productivity of our country.
As I stand here there are hundreds of students, recent graduates and summer students of our universities, who are lining up at the student employment centre on Dalhousie campus in Halifax. Do they not deserve something better than a one in ten chance at a job that, at best, pays minimum wage and is completely career-unrelated?
The brain-drain in Nova Scotia will spread to a brain-drain across Canada. Those out beating the pavement for jobs this summer are almost certain to be engaging in a futile search and their government is doing nothing to help them.
May 4, 1992

Mr. Speaker, one of the biggest barriers to getting people off the cycle of dependency created by our country's present social welfare system is that most people's earning potential is not sufficient to meet the needs of themselves or their families.
Under a plan to be announced later this month approximately 5,000 people from New Brunswick and British Columbia currently on social assistance will be encouraged to find jobs.
The goal of this program is to bring long-term unemployed people back into the work force where they will develop skills and attitudes that enable them to upgrade their income making meaningful employment more attractive than social assistance.
This program will mark the first step in better addressing the needs of people on social assistance who want the dignity associated with holding a full-time job.
I applaud the Minister of Employment and Immigration for his vision in bringing this program forward.

Mr. Speaker, the province of Ontario has traditionally provided about 40 per cent of the tax base for national programs such as medicare, post-secondary education and pensions.
The combination of the free trade agreement, exceedingly high taxation and the recession have taken a disastrous toll on the industrial and small business base in Ontario where hundreds of thousands are unemployed. This is not only devastating to families in Ontario, but because of its effect on federal government income, it is also devastating the rest of Canada which has already been severely hurt by the policies of the Conservative government.
We then have the NDP in Ontario. Can you imagine, Mr. Speaker, the NDP are now being questioned about their odd accounting manoeuvres in the Ontario budget just last week.
It is no wonder that Ontario's new Liberal premier-inwaiting, Lyn McLeod, called for a real job strategy and sound policies that would create confidence in the Ontario economy.
Meanwhile, the Canadian public cannot wait until they can get rid of the Tory government in Ottawa and the NDP in Ontario. They want to get back to common sense and responsible management of Canada's affairs.
Good leadership and integrity in public office are the keys to Canada's future.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip's assistant; Deputy Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, last week, the office of the leader of the Liberal Party announced that the leader of the party would make a major speech on Montreal's economy this weekend in Montreal. The inference was that we would hear a description of the kind of economic initiatives his party would like to implement in the area.
Those familiar with the Liberal leader's ideas must have expected to hear about major public works projects, probably costing billions of borrowed dollars, something we had come to expect when the Liberal Party was in power.
Surprise. The Liberal leader forgot his speech and merely expressed his own understanding of Montreal's problems, while of course putting all the blame on the present government.
I think a leader of a political party, who happens to be the Leader of the Opposition in this country, should have made the kind of speech he had led us to expect. He ought to know Canadians will not elect him for what he did or for what he did not do. What are his policies for the future?

Mr. Speaker, last week the Prime Minister agreed with my colleague, the member for Saanich-Gulf Islands, that our environment is "beyond partisan politics". However, when asked if he has been in contact with President Bush about attending

May 4, 1992
the earth summit in Brazil, the Prime Minister offered only insults.
As many Canadians have long suspected, the Prime Minister is part of the environmental crisis we face. One need look no further than global warming to find a federal energy policy promoting an increase, or a redfaced environment minister calling for stabilization despite a unanimous report by this Parliament calling for a 20 per cent reduction.
Sadly, over the past week, the U.S. has used its influence to blast a hole in the draft international treaty on global warming. It will stall emission caps, targets and timetables.
A report just completed found net savings of $2.7 trillion if the U.S. adopts an energy policy to fight global warming. Savings in Canada would run to hundreds of billions of dollars, the sort of money needed to save our world. Instead, Bush and Mulroney are choosing global warming, the politics of global suicide.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, good things do not always come in small packages. On Friday, I had the pleasure of announcing the relocation of an entire regional headquarters.
Yes, the Canadian Coast Guard's Great Lakes regional headquarters is coming to my riding of Sarnia-Lambton. Through Transport Canada, the Coast Guard is the second federal department to discover all that our community has to offer: the people, the quality of life, the community spirit, its location, its established transportation links, and on and on.
Over and over in this House I have been saying how great our community of Sarnia-Lambton is. Next year the Canadian Coast Guard's Great Lakes regional headquarters personnel will learn first hand. We welcome them with open arms.
To others out there, big or small, you do not know what you are missing. Come on down to Sarnia-Lambton and discover what the commotion is about.

Mr. Speaker, the serious impact of cross-border shopping on retailers in Canada's border communities continues. In spite of this on-going increase in cross-border shopping, the government continues to ignore the problem.
All reports from all communities affected have made it very clear that the number one attraction to lure shoppers to the U.S. is the price of gasoline.
Why does the government not give the serious problem caused by cross-border shopping the attention it deserves and drop the 8.5 cents a litre federal excise tax on gasoline?
That would have the immediate effect of encouraging thousands of Canadians to shop at home once again, as well as encouraging U.S. tourists to visit Canada in the 1992 tourist season.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, across Canada we are now celebrating National Forest Week.
Last week in Chetwynd, the current forestry capital of Canada, Prime Minister Mulroney, accompanied by the Minister of Forestry, Frank Oberle, launched a major new green plan initiative known as Tree Plant Canada.
Hufidreds of other cities and towns across the country will soon be involved in community tree planting programs aimed at encouraging and fostering the planting of over 325 million trees over the next six years.
Tree Plant Canada exemplifies Canada's commitment to sustainable forest management and maintaining the diversity of forest values, social, economic and environmental, for future generations.

Mr. Speaker, last week's events in Los Angeles should serve as a lesson to all of us in Canada. The combination of unemployment, poverty, lack of health care and education, as well as systemic discrimination and racism is deadly.
May 4, 1992

While we in Canada like to think that such violence could never occur here, many of the problems that led to the situation in L.A. are present on our own city streets. Police minority relations are strained, employment equity for visible minorities is still but a dream, and poverty is a reality for many in our cities.

The events in Los Angeles demonstrate that Canada should not follow the U.S. example with respect to race relations. Canada should continue to build a system that treats each individual with dignity and respect, and we must work hard to make ours a fair and equitable society.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to bring to the attention of the members of this House and to all Canadians that Spinal Health Week started on May 1. This date marks the beginning of that time of the year when many Canadians engage in the kind of seasonal activities often associated with back injuries. Such injuries are painful and may prevent people from going about their usual activities.
Mr. Speaker, I would also like to pay tribute to those Canadians who provide care for people who have suffered spinal trauma, whether slight or serious, and to the families of these patients.
A healthy spine helps us take full advantage of our Canadian way of life. That is why the people who promote spinal health and those who protect it deserve our support.

Mr. Speaker, I speak on behalf of the Aksmit family of Coquitlam, B.C. They have been told that they will be sent back to their native Czechoslovakia in a few days. Mr. and Mrs. Aksmit and their two young children left that country early in 1989 because they were being persecuted for their political beliefs, for refusing to join the Communist Party. This was before the velvet revolution changed that system.
The Aksmits gave up everything they had in Czechoslovakia in order to escape this persecution and offer their children a safe environment to grow up in. Arriving
Oral Questions
in Canada, both quickly found jobs, jobs they could continue to hold if they were allowed to stay. Their children entered Canadian schools and have excelled over the past three years.
In one day my office received over 60 calls from teachers and others in the community who want the Aksmits to stay in Canada. People are saying it would be cruel to force this family to be once more tom from their home because of political forces beyond their control and insensitive to their plight.
I hope the minister is listening and will respond with compassion in this matter and allow the Aksmits to remain here in Canada where they belong.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister. Canadians will know that over the last five years this government has taken $5 billion out of programs for children.
Children are at risk because the government in the next five years will take another $5 billion away from health and education programs. Children are at risk because the government is cutting social housing by almost $500 million over the next five years. Children are at risk because the government has deindexed the child benefit system to the tune of $3.5 billion. Children are at risk because the Prime Minister has reneged on his national child care program.
How could the government have the nerve to launch a PR program on children at risk today when it has done nothing to help the plight of a million children living in poverty?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, perhaps this is an opportunity to remind the hon. member that according to the United Nations and its human development index wherein it assessed 160 nations of the world, it was indicated that Canada was number one when it came to the whole issue of our educational system, our health care system, our environmental practices, all things that improve the quality of life. I think that is certainly a very

May 4, 1992
Oral Questions
clear indication that we are doing some things right in this country.
Today the Minister of National Health and Welfare announced further initiatives to those that have been taken in the last few weeks and months by the federal government. For example, I remind the hon. member that on December 11 the Prime Minister signed and ratified the Convention on the Rights of the Child. In my budget in February we brought out a new child benefit package that provides an additional $2.1 billion over a five-year period.
Today the Minister of National Health and Welfare outlined a very comprehensive program, a children's action plan and a child development initiative which provide a framework program for children at risk. They are all very important and I am sure important enough for the hon. member to support. I hope she does, along with her colleagues.

Mr. Speaker, we are sitting on a powder keg: poverty among our young people. What we need is a real program to fight poverty. In the last five years under this government, the Conservatives have taken $5 billion from funds that directly affect children. We need real programs for the 60 per cent of single mothers who live in poverty.
Can the Prime Minister tell us today whether this program provides one cent to feed hungry children?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows the child benefit package that was unveiled in the budget is part of a comprehensive plan.
It will, as I indicated, increase the support for lower income people to the tune of about $2.1 billion over a five-year period. It will provide assistance to the working poor and particularly help those families who find themselves in a situation where they have jobs but they are low paying jobs. We want to encourage the support for them.
The overhaul of the family allowance program is certainly an initiative which is finding favour with many
Canadians. What we are attempting to do here is to direct those resources in a more effective way and to direct those resources to those people in need, those families in need, and those children in need.

Mr. Speaker, I asked the Deputy Prime Minister how he can justify a $5 billion cutback in direct assistance to children at the same time as he asks us to congratulate him for a program that represents $100 million a year.
What is the intelligence of sending out food guidelines to families who have nothing in their refrigerators? What is putting our kids at risk is poverty.
The Prime Minister in the last federal election used child care and children as election fodder. He is not going to get away with it again.
I want to ask the Prime Minister veiy directly: What is there in this program, the program with the big C that actually deals with the little c, the children of this country?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think all children are a national priority for each and every one of us here. The best way for us to tackle poverty has to do with getting our financial structure in order. Following through on the Minister of Finance's budget that he brought down last February, the new child benefit plan will indeed put $2.1 billion into the hands of parents over the next five years.
Also, the program that the Minister of National Health and Welfare announced today is the third and fourth layer of our action plan for youngsters and the development of the child initiative that will be dealing with children at risk. We cannot do this alone and we have never said we could.
What we are doing is working with all levels of government, with agencies and with individuals in order to prevent, to promote, to protect and to join these partnerships. I do hope that the hon. member will join us.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of State for Youth.
May 4, 1992

Last week the federal government suddenly abandoned a very successful and popular inner city project after 10 years of support. This surprise announcement means that over 2,000 students will be left on the street, put at risk by the very government that today announced its great interest in children and poverty.
Earlier I delivered to the minister dozens of letters asking Ottawa to support this program. For only $65,000 Challenge '92 could be providing 35 jobs in nine of Winnipeg's poorest neighbourhoods.
Will the minister not have his government reconsider this decision and support these very deserving people?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre H. Cadieux (Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport); Minister of State (Youth); Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I did receive a communication today from the hon. member dated April 27 and I will indeed look into the situation.
In the meantime I want to remind my hon. colleague that the program was increased. Some of the funds were increased in Manitoba in particular. I understand the particular program to which he is referring did not meet certain criteria, but I will look into it.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the minister of employment.
Yesterday morning, Sunday morning in Winnipeg, students began to line up at 10 a.m. looking for work. They stood there all night waiting for the office to open, and this morning they were joined by several hundred more. They are all looking for jobs. They all want to continue their education, which this government claims to be a priority.
Will the minister now admit that there is a crisis in student employment and approach his colleagues for more money to help us through the crisis this summer?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, notwithstanding the fact that we have to spend taxpayers' money responsibly, we have managed through a serious exercise toward deficit reduction to increase the amount of dollars that go into the Challenge program for this fiscal year so that these students can be provided with jobs.
Oral Questions
The hon. member should realize that the responsibility to help students in Canada rests with everyone, every stakeholder in the economy. That is why we have these programs in place to encourage the private sector to do its part and help those students attain gainful employment in the summer so that they may pursue their studies. Of course it is an issue of money. If we had all the money in the world we could do more, but we have to spend responsibly.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
I am sure that everyone in this House, as well as all other Canadians, share the horror of what happened last week in Los Angeles. I suppose it reminds us all of what happens when any country ignores the devastating effects of racism.
One year ago in this House legislation was passed for the establishment of a race relations foundation. That legislation has never been proclaimed. When will the legislation be proclaimed so that we can begin establishing this foundation to show those Canadians who are often the targets of racism that this country and this Parliament are serious about combating racism in this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we made fighting racism a very important priority of this government. We recognized very early in our mandate the evil that it is. We implemented significant programs to help Canadians in their awareness and actually to do something to eradicate this disease from our system.
We have implemented a very important series of programs and policies in partnership with many different institutions of the society. I can point with pride to the contribution that was made by the Canadian Association of Broadcasters that last year brought forward a program of some $10 million in public awareness and information. One might examine the effect of that year in that attitudes have improved across Canada and we do feel better about ourselves.

May 4, 1992
Oral Questions
That being said, though, I do recognize that even one act of racism is too many. All of us have to do more and more to help remove this sinful disease from our system.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the minister.
Why did the government bring forward legislation for the establishment of a race relations foundation if it did not intend to implement it? Why did the government have this House vote on the race relations foundation if the government did not intend to act on it?
Racism cannot be a public relations exercise. Is this government or is not this government committed to the establishment of a race relations foundation and when, if it is?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the establishment of a race relations foundation is a very important priority of this government and is now awaiting proclamation. There was a delay in terms of the actual date as was announced by the Minister of Finance.
However, one must recognize the fact that we have diverted substantial parts of the budget of my ministry to fight racism and discrimination and to bring forward programs of integration and equality. In fact when we first began this was the department of fancy food and festivals, and today we are more and more the department that promotes equality and making sure that our citizenship is one level of citizenship for all Canadians.
I might point with pride to the partnership that we have developed with government, police as an institution and the community-
We may have to move on.

Mr. Speaker, it is clear on this particular issue of the race relations foundation that this is the government of fancy footwork because we still have no answer about what this government is going to do.
My supplementary question is for the Deputy Prime Minister. There is no doubt that questions of racism in this country are also related to social programs, to health programs, and certainly to unemployment.
As we look across this country, we see levels of youth unemployment up to approximately 17 per cent, high unemployment in aboriginal communities reaching 80 per cent in some communities, and the same in many communities across the country for black youth.
Is the Deputy Prime Minister and his government prepared to look seriously at initiating employment programs in these particularly hard hit sectors of youth, of visible minorities, and of aboriginal people?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member should know that $3.4 billion will be spent on training, on different employment programs, and on Community Futures programs.
Throughout our programming, these groups that the hon. member mentioned are targeted as priority groups that receive assistance on employment in the vein that she referred to.
Notwithstanding the fact that we have had to streamline certain programs, these minority groups will not suffer from these cuts because we have maintained the same level of financing for these employment programs.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration. The recession continues to wreak havoc in the Montreal area, where unemployment is at an unacceptable level of 12.7 per cent. Among young people, the severity of the recession is even more obvious and unemployment is nearly 20 per cent.
When will the minister answer Montrealers' cries of alarm and finally give young people hope by offering them a real job creation program?

Mr. Speaker, since 1987 our action in the Montreal area has been based on a plan drawn up with the community and emphasizing high technology as a means of development. That is why we invested a lot of money in Canadair, which developed the regional jet, and we also invested heavily in establishing the space agency. We were the first government in Canada to invest in the Quebec Federation of Labour's solidarity fund and thus
May 4, 1992

helped set up that fund. We continue to work to create high-tech jobs, the jobs of the future.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the minister does not seem to understand the seriousness of the problem.
Today's youth are both frustrated and demoralized. What does the minister have to say to young people who are unable to pay for their education because there is no work? How can he expect our youth to have confidence in this country and in the future when one in five cannot find a job in Montreal?

Mr. Speaker, I think that the people of Montreal can again see the hypocrisy of the opposition party, which in this House fought a bill that we put forward to give the required funding to young people and everyone who did not have what was necessary to hold the new jobs. This opposition party not only fought this bill in the House but had the Senate oppose it and prevent it from passing, even though it provided $800 million for new jobs.

Mr. Speaker, in less than 40 hours, a Canadian citizen, Mr. Joseph Faulder, is to be executed in the state of Texas.
The Secretary of State for External Affairs has launched a diplomatic protest to the United States government and has also sent a letter to the governor of the state of Texas. I am asking the minister today if, on behalf of the Canadian government, she will file for an injunction for a stay of this execution or, as an alternative, file an amicus brief advising the court of the lack of due process in this entire matter.
I am asking the minister today, on behalf of the House and the people of Canada, to protect the rights of this Canadian citizen.

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, just for the edification of the House, the U.S. authorities appear to have breached the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations by failing in their duty to inform Faulder of his right to consult with a representative of the Canadian government.
Oral Questions
Those are the grounds on which I wrote the letter. We protested strongly through our embassy in Washington to the U.S. government. The U.S. government has undertaken to present this point of view to the governor of Texas. The process is still going through appeal. We will take whatever action we think is appropriate to see that clemency is exercised.

Mr. Speaker, to the same minister, less than an hour ago. I spoke to Mr. Faulder's lawyer, Miss Babcock. She advises me that with the exception of the letter and the appeal to the governor of the state of Texas that nothing else has been done. They are appearing some time later on this afternoon in a court.
I am prepared to assist and I am sure our side is prepared to assist in whatever way we can in order to seek this injunction or to assist in this application for an amicus order. I ask the minister if she would consider that and take that under advisement.

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I will certainly take it under advisement. I do not want to comment on the case itself. I have looked at it fairly thoroughly. As the hon. member knows, we have not had much time to work on this because the convention was breached. My legal people as well as people in my office are examining all aspects of it with a view to anything that we might do.

Mr. Speaker, no one doubts that the social and racial context in the United States is quite different from that in Canada. Nevertheless, there is increasing concern in Canada among visible minority groups about the kinds of relationships that are being manifested across this country between them and the judicial system, the police and government.
My question to the Deputy Prime Minister is this: Will the government consider responding positively to the plea of a variety of visible minority groups that there be launched some kind of inquiry into racism and the judicial system in law enforcement and the Public Service? More immediately, will this government examine the conditions in the Criminal Code which regulate the use of deadly force in the pursuit and apprehension of suspects?

May 4, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. member for that question because it raises a very important concern.
One of the main priorities of this government is what we would call inclusive justice and that is making the justice system more reflective of the reality of all Canadians. We have launched two major initiatives in this area with respect to women and the law and aboriginal justice, but there remain a number of concerns particularly with respect to immigrant groups and their feelings of alienation particularly in our large urban centres.
I have been consulting over the past few weeks with the mayors of the big cities of Canada to talk about the possibility of drawing together some kind of strategy related to urban crime and urban safety that would address some of the considerations that he has raised. I think they relate not simply to the judicial system and to the activities of the police, but also to broader social problems that we have to look at in a comprehensive way.
With respect to the use of deadly force, I can say to the hon. member, as he well knows there is a provision in the Criminal Code, the fleeing felon rule which does authorize the use of force by a law enforcement officer in conducting an arrest where his or her own safety or the safety of others under his or her control may be at risk.
There is some concern that the rule is broad and I am hoping to bring forward legislation within the next few months into this House to deal with the concern that people have about the breadth of that rule.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate that answer. I hope that the minister would also reconsider the question of the Court Challenges Program as it applies to racial minorities.
My second question, addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister, is that the visible minority communities are very concerned about the rejection by his government and by the Official Opposition of a proposed amendment to the Charter of Rights and Freedoms which would have provided for a commitment on the part of governments to preserve and promote racial and ethnic equality-
My question to the Deputy Prime Minister: My God, will this government not reconsider?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is not quite clear how that question should be addressed because it addresses the question of conformity of laws with the charter and the principles of the charter, but a change such as the hon. member mentions would in fact involve a constitutional amendment. This would of course add to the agenda that is already before the Government of Canada in trying to resolve our constitutional problems.
I do think that we have within the hands of responsible authorities at all three levels of government in this country enough legal devices to do the job.
What we need is political commitment, will and creativity. That is what we should address ourselves to.
 * *

Mr. Speaker, I have in my hand a contract between Global Tek of Vancouver and the National Research Council. The contract is for the development of a meningitis test. Under this contract, the research clearly belongs to the company. However, the government is claiming ownership of that research.
I brought this matter to the attention of the minister for science last week. Will he tell us why the government has misappropriated this invention in clear violation of this contract and the government's published policies?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, may I first thank the hon. member for giving me notice of the question, which he did last week.
I have looked into this in a very preliminary way. As far as the National Research Council is concerned, there is nothing in the IRAP contract which has anything to do with the intellectual property rights being held by NRC. NRC does not want the intellectual property rights. When you have an IRAP contract, we make no claim to the intellectual property rights.
May 4, 1992

The issue here is that some of the work was done in government laboratories and it is a distinction that has to be drawn between the NRC labs and other department laboratories. The issue is another department and Global Tek itself. That is under debate.

Mr. Speaker, it cannot be under debate to any reasonable person because the contract with the National Research Council specified that the work would be done in the Health and Welfare laboratories here in Ottawa.
The contract insists in paragraph 6 of schedule B that the property belongs to the company. By misappropriating Global Tek's invention, this government is saying to Canadian companies: "If we see what we like, we will steal it".
Will the minister immediately denounce this misappropriation of Global Tek's property? Will he restore it immediately to Global Tek and will he ensure that the government never again abuses its power and authority in this way?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me say once again that this is not a dispute between the National Research Council and Global Tek.
This is really a dispute between Health and Welfare Canada and Global Tek. There is nothing in the contract with IRAP that says that Global Tek has a claim to whatever work is done in National Health and Welfare laboratories. I will offer to use my good offices to see if we can resolve this dispute as quickly as possible.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport.
It is now just a matter of time before Canadian Airlines announces the detailed results of its negotiations with American Airlines, a deal which could fundamentally change the nature of the transportation industry in Canada. Meanwhile, the government is maintaining a total silence on this and other developments in the airline industry. Why is the government burying its head in the sand on this issue? Does it have no opinion at all on the number of airlines that we should have in Canada, the value of a flag carrier or the feasibility of an airline merger? What does the government propose to do?
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, our position was made known publicly quite some time ago. There are existing laws concerning the ownership of airlines, restricting it to 25 per cent.
The airlines have been made aware that if they have any intentions of changing that or if they have any plan that would be of some help to them if we change that, they should come forward. To date, I have received no application to that effect.

Precisely, Mr. Speaker, and this is the problem that we are having with the government not giving any indication to the industry where it hopes that industry is going to go.
Every day we have airline analysts getting up and saying that very important fundamental changes are happening in that industry. Yet, we have no idea where the Government of Canada stands on any of the issues that are being raised or where it hopes to see the airlines end up in the future.
Why is the government not doing or saying anything that gives an indication of what its policy is? Is the government simply content to wait until the industry is lost to Canadians?

Mr. Speaker, with all due respect, those who are the most concerned about the survival of the airline industry are the airline companies themselves. They certainly know what is best for them in the future, and if they have any plans to ask for changes in the present laws they will certainly apply to us.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
I want to begin by congratulating the Minister of National Health and Welfare for finally admitting that his government's social and economic policies have completely failed Canada's children. The band-aid public relations approach, announced today, offers only $2 a day for a poor child in Canada. So much for the government's commitment to eliminate child poverty by the year 2000.

Oral Questions
Does the minister seriously think that two loonies a day will even begin to solve the many problems Canada's poor children face every single day?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, perhaps we could start with the importance that this government places on children with the summit that was held at the United Nations in September, which the Prime Minister co-hosted. There was the ratification of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child in December, 1991 and then we moved forward with the Minister of Finance's child benefit package, which is $2.1 billion over a period of five years. The Minister of National Health and Welfare announced Brighter Futures this morning.
We are targeting the funds that we have specifically to an area, and it is the area of children at risk. We would like to do more but we know we have hit exactly where the people of Canada want us to put their dollars, and it is to help the children at risk.

Mr. Speaker, this government has taken billions and billions of dollars from programs to help Canada's children and this action plan announced today challenges individual Canadians to solve the problems of Canada's children. It does not address the responsibility of the Canadian government to Canada's children.
Two loonies a day per poor child is an insult to Canadian children. When will this government change its policies which have hurt Canadian children so much, and why does the Canadian government refuse to accept its responsibilities?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is important for all hon. members to know, and the Canadian public to realize, that this government spends some $15 billion annually on social services directed to families and children. That is a lot of money.
The initiatives I announced in the budget and the initiatives announced by the Minister of National Health and Welfare will add, over time, an additional $3 billion worth of support for families and children.
The hon. member should recognize that. The money is not coming from this Parliament; it is coming from the taxpayers of Canada and we should be grateful for that.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip's assistant; Deputy Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport, who is responsible for the Montreal region.
Last week, the office of the leader of the Liberal Party announced that he would make a major speech in Montreal on the economic base of the Montreal region, but it seems that he forgot to make his speech. Nevertheless, I think that Montrealers must be expecting some information about their economic base.
I would ask the minister responsible for the Montreal region to make up for the lack of information provided by the Liberal Party.

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has rightly understood that, just as when they formed the government, the Liberals still forget about Montreal. The Leader of the Liberal Party certainly did not want to run the risk of being reminded that, unlike his party, this government has done some very specific things for the economic future of Montreal.
I think the hon. gentlemen went a little beyond the purpose of Question Period. The hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State.
The C.D. Howe Institute expressed some rather controversial opinions in a study released last week. Some writers advocate transferring the powers and obligations
May 4, 1992

for promoting and protecting both of Canada's official languages to the provinces.
Can the Secretary of State tell us if his government approves of this proposal that only the provinces should be responsible for language issues?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, this issue was debated at several constitutional meetings in recent months. The position of the federal government is that there should be a clear and precise clause in the Constitution asking every level of government to promote and help develop linguistic minorities throughout the country. This is the position that we supported. It is the position demanded by organizations representing linguistic minorities, and it is also the position that the government will continue to defend.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question. The 1988 Official Languages Act gives the federal government the responsibility to work with the provinces to enrich services for linguistic minorities, including the right to minority language education and schooling as guaranteed in the Constitution.
The Economic Council of Canada reported last week that there are shortages of teachers in all disciplines in French language schools outside Quebec. What will the federal government do to address the situation and possibly correct it now?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we are in very active negotiations at the moment with the provinces of British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Ontario.
As a matter of fact, I am meeting the minister of education for Ontario tomorrow or Wednesday. That is very much on the front burner. We are trying with each of the provinces to sign bilateral agreements to address exactly the issue that my hon. colleague has raised.
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, my question is also for the Secretary of State. It has already been two years since an agreement in principle was concluded between the federal government and the provincial government for the construction of a French college in northern Ontario. When the process got under way, it gave hope to the residents of that region, but then it went nowhere. What does the Secretary of State intend to do to revive this promise and keep this initiative alive after it has been stalled for two years?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, this is precisely the main issue on the agenda that will be discussed tomorrow or Wednesday with Mr. Allen from Ontario, as I was saying earlier today to the member for Ottawa-Vanier, in order to try to resolve the issue of French language colleges. There is not only the college in the north, there is also the college in the south and the one in Ottawa. I must tell you that we are moving on the project. We meet regularly. We have to discuss questions of cost, definition and location. We may not make progress as quickly as some would like, but I must tell you that a great deal has been done in recent months. And I would hope that following this week's meeting, we will be able to come to a definite arrangement.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary. The Secretary of State just mentioned that this matter has dragged on for nearly two years. He must realize that young francophones in northern Ontario have also been waiting for two years and that northern Ontario residents are sick and tired of listening to both governments blame each other for failing to act.
Could the Secretary of State announce today how much money he intends to make available to the province, so it will at least appoint a board of governors by the end of June?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member's premise is that both levels of government are blaming each other. I beg to differ. I never blamed Ontario. Negotiations are being

May 4, 1992
Oral Questions
conducted, and I believe they are going well. Views differ on some points, especially on the amounts to be contributed by both parties. These matters are being dealt with. There is no question of blaming anyone.

Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the Minister of Veterans Affairs, my question is for the government House leader.
As some of us know and perhaps all of us remember, yesterday was the 50th anniversary of the battle of the Atlantic. There were certain ceremonies held in the national capital, also in Halifax and other parts of Canada to recognize the contribution of the unsung heroes of that war a long time ago, that is, the merchant marines.

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, hon. members, it is my great pleasure to present to the House the Government of Canada's action plan for children.
The action plan represents the government's response to the declaration issued by world leaders at the 1990 world summit for children which the Prime Minister co-chaired. The world declaration made an urgent appeal to give every child a better future. It called on member nations to develop plans of action to improve the situation of children in all countries.
Canada has responded with a plan to create brighter futures for our children and those in developing countries.

According to international standards, children in Canada live healthy, secure lives and receive all the help they need from their families and communities. However, we must not let ourselves be lulled into complacency.
Our plan includes an assessment of the challenges faced by all who are concerned about child care-parents, governments, business, workers, native groups and all our communities-and stresses the federal government's commitment to deal with the risks to which, unfortunately, too many of our children are exposed.

My colleague, the Minister of National Health and Welfare announced this morning a program entitled Brighter Futures.

This program is based on measures that have already been taken by the Government of Canada: the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the government proposal for a new child benefit that will provide increased assistance to the families that need it most.

This action plan forms an important part of Brighter Futures as does the child development initiative for children at risk.
This action plan can enable all of us to work together to ensure that no child is at risk. Ultimately, our strength as a nation is reflected in our care for those who are most vulnerable.
It is up to all of us to create brighter futures for our children.

speechtext: With respect to federal garnishing orders, are there delays of more than six weeks for the moneys garnished to reach their appropriate recipients and, if so, (a) for what reasons (b) what does the government intend to do to alleviate such delays?

speakeroldname: Mr. Robert D. Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
The Family Orders and Agreements Enforcement Assistance Act affects a variety of federal monies payable to debtor spouses by certain government departments source departments such as, Revenue Canada Taxation, Employment and Immigration Canada and Health and Welfare Canada. Since the garnishment process began in May 1988, approximately 300,000 garnishment actions, resulting from 100,000 garnishment summonses, totalling over $56.6 million have been completed.
It is difficult to precisely determine the length of time required to garnishee each of the funds from the various source departments. The garnishment process usually takes an average of six to seven weeks from the time the Department of Justice is advised of amounts available for garnishment by the source departments to the time that the funds are remitted to the provincial and territorial courts and enforcement agencies. This is in addition to the initial 35 days required to action a garnishment summons provided for in the act.
An important factor which influences the length of time it takes to transfer money to recipients is the government's interdepartmental settlement process which governs every transfer of garnisheed funds from the source departments to the Department of Justice. Once the funds have been received by the Department of Justice they are then immediately disbursed to the courts and enforcement agencies. This process requires the involvement of three departments: Justice, the source department and Supply and Services. The IS process provides for checks and balances to ensure that
May 4, 1992

Routine Proceedings
sums of money transferred are properly recorded and reconciled with appropriate audit trails. The Department of Justice must ensure that all moneys garnisheed are properly reflected in the accounts of each debtor and that notification is issued to each court and agency along with the appropriate cheque.
The volume of garnishment actions undertaken and the number of source funds subject to garnishment such as unemployment insurance benefits, Canada Pension Plan payments, income tax refunds, interest on regular Canada Savings Bonds and old age Security payments also influence the average time for the transfer of funds. As moneys may become available from more than one source department at any one time, it is not possible to simply advise each department ahead of time of the amount to garnishee. Instead, every department which has source funds blocks the benefits payable and indicates the amounts available to the Department of Justice. This method ensures that no excess moneys are garnisheed other then those required to satisfy the support order and it is unique to this garnishment process. In most other debt collection systems it is possible to advise the source of the moneys of the amount to garnishee and then proceed to collect. As a result this adds to the length of time required to garnishee.
Hiking all this into account, the Department of Justice is administering this complex process in the most efficient and effective manner possible. Nevertheless, through ongoing discussions with other government departments, the Department of Justice will continue to look for ways in which the time required to garnishee federal moneys can be reduced while continuing to ensure that shortcuts in the process are not taken which will jeopardize the ability to garnishee monies for the benefit of creditors throughout Canada.

Mr. Speaker, the bill under consideration, Bill C-63, evolves as a result of the budget announcement of this government on February 25 of this year the decision to cut some 46 Crown agencies, corporations, and commissions for a projected saving of $22 million.
This legislation deals with six of these particular agencies, including Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, Economic Council of Canada, International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law
Reform Commission, and the Science Council of Canada.
Earlier in my remarks I noted the importance of the government having non-partisan, arm's length advice in areas as important as energy, the environment, economic policy, science policy, employment, and international peace and security.
Each of these areas is very controversial, in many of which academics disagree, participants disagree, and everyone needs a forum in which to put forward their views and have an opportunity to persuade government of their views.
These councils have served as honest brokers as well as doing original research. They have brought together people in an honest and open fashion to discuss these ideas in different forums and have given them an opportunity to write dissenting views and to present their ideas to the public.
In our society where we worry about openness in government and participation among as many groups as possible, it is sad to see one of these great opportunities being put aside by the government. It will take another government months, if not years, to replace the infrastructure being tom apart without any heart by this government.
The Economic Council of Canada has served a good purpose. The Science Council has been excellent in its advice. There are no more important issues than those dealing with employment and immigration. One sees one controversial report after another as this government moves and zig-zags through its immigration and employment policies.
When leadership is lacking so clearly within the government, how can those people then turn around and say that they do not need impartial advice? They know what they are doing. In fact, just the opposite is true.
As for the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, it came into existence at a time when the world was undergoing major change in the relations among its dominant players. People began to question nuclear arms both as an aggressive first strike and as a defensive mechanism, and now we have the opportunity to open up discussions and deal with regional battles.
Instead of having one more arm, one more set of ideas out there, one more opportunity to criticize and talk to the people, we have pulled back. We say we do not need that; it is a waste of money.
May 4, 1992

At no point in our history can one marginalize peace and security and particularly right now when it takes a lot of concentration and a lot of original thinking to understand the significance of the changes going on throughout Europe, Africa, Asia, and the Americas. What are these going to mean for us? How do we bring people together?
One does not form a group of people who are doing good intellectual work and who have contacts throughout the world. You do not disgroup them, disband them, and then regroup them. How do you rebuild the confidence of the communities involved? How do you get people who are working together to come together again after they have been forced into unemployment and dispersed because you thought their ideas were worthless?
They become political pawns, exactly the opposite of the way we set them out to be. We told them at one point to go do their work, come out with some interesting ideas, do research, go spend time in the library, get on the phone to their friends around the world, talk to them, see what is happening, bring us some ideas, help us, in the case of the Economic Council of Canada, to get us out of this education mess, help us get out of this economic malaise we are in.
Suddenly government says that no, it did not really want their ideas. It is too dangerous for it. It has its agenda.
Canadians are tired of this government's agenda. They want to hear what else is going on in the world. They do not pay governments to have propaganda machines. They pay them to present good ideas that we can work on.
Instead of having other critics out in the system, it is reducing everything to the political and lowest common denominator. We object very, very strongly to this. I can tell you from personal experience that the work done by, for example, the Social Science and Humanities Research Council which will come up under other legislation-I hope to discuss it more fully then-is fundamental to the maintenance of an independent, intellectual community in this country.
Government Orders
We owe it to these people to be there to support them. We owe it to them to oppose this legislation.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Canadian Institute International Peace and Security was established by Parliament with the agreement of all parties in August 1984.
This, you will recall, was at the height of the cold war. At that time, there was a deep and growing concern among Canadians about the possibility of nuclear war. There was a strong desire to see Canada do everything within its power to nudge states toward freer, more peaceful means of interacting.
The government of the day, indeed all the parties, agreed that there was a need for a publicly funded institute to study and promote fresh ideas in the peace and security field. Accordingly, the CUPS was established with the purpose of increasing knowledge and understanding of issues relating to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective.
Throughout the past seven years, CUPS has fulfilled its mandate quite well. The institute has undertaken and sponsored timely research, conferences and seminars on a number of topics including non-proliferation, Canadian defence policy, peacemaking and regional conflicts. It has produced a host of relevant, thoughtful publications that have enhanced the quality of debate on these issues both in Canada and abroad.
The institute has built a high calibre library collection of peace and security. It has also, through its grants and awards programs, fostered scholarship, public discussion and understanding of peace and security issues among a wide cross-section of Canadians.
There can be no doubt that CUPS has made a positive contribution to peace and security dialogue in Canada. This has been a benefit to policy makers and the public alike.
Now that the cold war is over, there is no less need for Canadian security policy to be informed by the best possible analysis of international developments. The present era is marked by uncertainty and instability in many parts of the world. In many regions, there is the danger of fragmentation into rivalry and disorder at a time when international co-operation and collaboration is most needed.

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
The security challenges of the 1990s are much broader than the security challenges of the 1980s. They encompass political, economic, environmental, military, social, humanitarian and demographic issues among others.
To address these challenges effectively, the government and all Canadians will continue to require independent sources of research and analysis of international events. The need to husband resources, however, has led the government to reconsider how this function of independent research and analysis can best and most effectively be performed. In this CUPS is like the other agencies that have already been the subject of debate on this bill. The general need to husband resources is the reason for this bill. It has been the same for many others that have come before Parliament in recent years.
There is a need, which the budget recently presented to the House made very clear. Nonetheless, it is not one which we would expect hon. members opposite to understand clearly. If they were to look they would see that many sources of independent foreign policy research and analysis already exist in Canada. They exist in the universities and their associated research centres. They exist in bodies such as the Canadian Institute of International Affairs, the Canadian Institute of Strategic Studies, the Canadian Centre Arms Control and Disarmament, and Le centre quebecois pour les relations intemationales.
The government itself provides support for independent scholarship, analysis, and discussion in the peace and security field through programs in External Affairs and International Trade Canada and the Department of National Defence.
In light of these numerous independent sources of activity and advice and the need to reduce costs, overlap and duplication, the government has concluded that Canada can no longer afford a separate publicly funded peace and security institute. Discussions are now under way to determine what continuing resources will be transferred to External Affairs and International Trade Canada as a result of the wind-up of CUPS.
The goal will continue the elements of work that were undertaken by CUPS without duplicating what is already being done by the private sector or elsewhere in government. Wherever possible emphasis will be placed on fostering activities among independent researchers and
organizations that will advance understanding, knowledge and public discussion in the peace and security field.
In so doing we will take into account the concept of co-operative security which the government has made a priority. The government looks forward to the time when it can announce the results of these discussions. We will continue to meet the security challenges of the 1990s with the benefit of an independent, active and knowledgeable peace and security community in Canada.
