subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to speak today in this House on second reading of Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies.
In the federal budget tabled in this House on February 25, 1992 the government announced its intention to eliminate, consolidate, defer or privatize 46 Crown agencies, corporations and commissions, all for a projected saving of $22 million per year.
This bill deals with six of the forty-six agencies that went on the chopping block on March 10 with the introduction of Bill C-63. The six are: the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council; the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security or better known as CUPS; the Economic Council of Canada; the International Centre for Ocean Development; the Law Reform Commission; and the Science Council of Canada. We agree that some on the longer list of 46 have to go. Many of them are extravagant. However many were established by this very government.
The Liberal Party is not opposed to the principle of privatization, but we do not support government policies which call for the limitation of organizations which continue to serve a useful public policy purpose.
There are several of the organizations which give the Canadian people a huge bang for their buck. The above mentioned in particular are not only useful but in the past have been proven to be invaluable.
This divestiture, this dismantling, is nothing short of a cynical attempt by this government to silence its critics. The critic to which I am specifically referring is the Reform Party. By axing these organizations they will no longer be able to present an independent perspective on
May 4, 1992

public policy, a perspective which time and time again has proven to be different from that of this government.
This act by its very nature will shift responsibilities embodied in the mandate of these various organizations to corresponding government departments. This defeats the whole purpose of why they were set up in the first place. All were set up to act in an independent fashion to advise the government and the public on the direction of public policy.
Now the government plans to advise itself. Worse still, the government will begin to rely more heavily on advice from such agencies as the Fraser Institute of Vancouver. Who does this agency represent? It is backed by and serves big business. Given this and given this government's record, the very thought of the loss of these bodies of independent thought shakes me to the core.
This government preaches that it is committed to making Canada more competitive. Yet it is proceeding with a bill that will eliminate some of the more important Canadian bodies which provide us with leading edge data, analysis and direction.
Over 300 people will be out of jobs as a result of this government's decision to wind up these agencies. The Canadian taxpayer has benefited considerably from these same agencies. Perhaps I could just briefly outline them.
The Science Council of Canada between the years of 1967 and 1992 recommended the creation of a Canadian space agency, urged Canadians to recycle, published reports on sustainable agriculture, water supply, biotechnology and technology for cold regions.
The abolition of the Science Council silences a respected independent review of this government's weak record on science and technology. The argument that the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology can step in and cover the council's functions is absolutely nuts. The Prime Minister chairs this board. Is he going to criticize himself? I would think not.
As we head into a much more competitive future, as science and technology becomes more and more important to sustaining human life on the planet and to improving quality of life, this government is going to cut back on science and technology. It is like cutting off one's nose to spite one's face.
Government Orders
The Economic Council of Canada was established in 1963 under the Economic Council of Canada Act to provide advice on how Canada can achieve the highest possible levels of employment and efficient production in order that the country may enjoy a high and consistent rate of economic growth and that all Canadians may share in rising living standards.
It undertakes research either on its own initiative or at the request of government. It operates at arm's length from ministers to provide independent advice to the minister, primarily the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology.
Between 1963 and 1992 the Economic Council issued reports and recommendations dealing with productivity, competitiveness, education, health, retraining, and most recently a report on the economic implications of Quebec separation.
As the Leader of the Opposition expressed in this House last week, he worked for many years with the Economic Council of Canada when he was a minister. The council criticized the government of the day and that is its prerogative. It made recommendations. Some were used and some were not. As my leader says, at least it was an independent voice, providing an independent view. Canadians had access to the other side. They were able to make their own decisions based on information. In this way it has contributed to the democratization of the public policy process.
The Law Reform Commission was established in 1971 by the Law Reform Commission Act. It reports to Parliament through the Minister of Justice. Its mandate is to maintain ongoing review of the statutes of Canada, to make recommendations for improvement, modernization and reform of legislation. It undertakes some research in house, contracts out other work to consultants on a full or part-time basis. It holds seminars and conferences, visits universities and schools, publishes articles in various journals.
Between 1970 and 1992 the Law Reform Commission issued 32 reports, 61 working papers, 76 studies containing recommendations covering Criminal Code reform, hate propaganda, plea bargaining, safeguarding genetic heritage, pornography, euthanasia, sexual assault, arson, mental disorder, and on and on. As of 1990 the commission's studies have been cited in 211 reported Canadian court decisions, 39 of which were Supreme Court of Canada decisions.

Government Orders
With the proposed elimination of the Law Reform Commission, Canada will be one of only three Commonwealth countries without an independent law reform body. We in Canada will now be in the company of Bangladesh and Zimbabwe.
The present Minister of Justice has been trying to silence the commission, her biggest critic since 1990. She left the commission without a quorum for two years, which made it impossible for the commission to approve any reports which would have included suggested changes to federal legislation.
Another one is the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. It was established in 1984 under its own act of Parliament. Its mandate was to increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relating to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective, with particular emphasis on arms control, disarmament, defence and conflict resolution. It undertakes research in house and supports research projects by others in Canada and overseas. It publishes books, background papers, magazines and teaching materials. It provides grants to NGOs and individuals for public education activities. It organizes conferences and seminars and funds scholarships awards and academic exchanges. It is a very busy organization and has an annual budget of approximately $5 million, and this government has cut it out.
For the little money spent CUPS has established a research and information library, developed a school education curriculum program, supported Canadian scholars, and has become known world-wide for its development of a first-class centre for peace and security, offering a Canadian perspective in the context of a tempestuous global reality. To do away with this agency during a time of unprecedented global change is terribly short-sighted.
The government says Canadians will save $22 million by this miserly move. I have tried to provide a sketch to this House of what Canadian taxpayers will lose as a result of the government's over-zealous decision to put these agencies on the block.
Because of the axing of these agencies, Canadians will be deprived of studies such as the Economics of Health
Care and the Economics of Education and of analyses such as the ones I mentioned previously.
I have been pleased to speak in this House on this motion. I would ask the government on behalf of all Canadians to reinstate these six agencies and not pass this bill that is presently before the House.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank you for letting me participate in this debate. I want to focus on my disagreement again on the dropping of the six major instruments of government, not all of which I will speak on in detail. I want to repeat so that everybody understands exactly what this government is up to and what it is cutting.
First it is cutting the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. Shame. Stupid.
Second is the Law Reform Commission of Canada, article 34(4) dissolved. Shame. Stupid.
Third is the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, article 5. Shame. Stupid.
Fourth is the Economic Council of Canada. Shame. Stupid, and I will come back to that in a minute.
Fifth is the International Centre for Ocean Development. Stupid and shameful.
Sixth is the Science Council of Canada.
I agree with everything that has been said in opposition to this, even if I have not heard the remarks up to now on all of these things. I want to deal specifically with a couple of these agencies and address myself to the absolute stupidity. If I could use the word hypocrisy, I would.
I want to deal with the International Centre for Ocean Development.
Off the east coast of this country we are in a crisis over fisheries management. We have had the spectacle of the minister flying in a helicopter out on a one-day demonstration against the loss of fisheries stock off the east coast of Canada.
Did his visit do anything to help fishery produce? No. Did his visit have anything to do with genuine scientific information? No, it was a political visit designed to placate the feelings of those fishermen off the east coast of Canada who are facing hard times.
May 4, 1992

The way to restore the fisheries is through scientific information and hard facts. How do we get scientific information? We set up the International Centre for Ocean Development. Does this government really want to discover what is wrong with the fisheries loss off the east coast? I do not think so. It does not give a fig, not a damn.
Why would it cut off the one instrument we have that is directly designed to deal with the offshore fisheries of this country if it is really concerned about the people of Newfoundland and the maritimes?
Mr. Speaker, explain it to me because you are the person who has to oversee this debate. If you could respond, perhaps you could explain to me why this government thinks that cutting off its nose to spite its face in terms of the research of the fisheries is actually going to save the Canadian people money.
This is stupid. How can it sit over there as a government and suggest that it is concerned about ocean problems and fisheries problems while the only instrument it has to deal with resolving those problems from a scientific and technical point of view is being cut off?
Then it goes to Europe and says: "Oh, help us. Please help us".
Do you know what its philosophy is? It is like the murderer who kills his mother and his father and then goes to court and pleads for mercy because he is an orphan. He is an orphan because of his own actions. This government is cutting off the one instrument we have.
The other area I want to talk about is the Science Council of Canada. How many of us here in moments of great reflection and sombre, sober deep thought about the future of this country have heard cabinet ministers get up and talk about global economy, productivity, competitiveness?
This government is spending $15 million sending a travelling road show around this country talking about productivity and being more competitive in the global market.
This is the outfit that spent $1 million to give a Harvard professor a task to find out what was wrong with our economy. On page 69 of the report he said one of the problems is we have lost the secondary and tertiary base of manufacturing due to the free trade agreement. After it received his report for $1 million, it spent another $15
Government Orders
million going around the country saying we have to be more productive. The government members are holding hands like at some kind of economic prayer meeting, saying: "Oh, Lord, please help us from ourselves".
The one instrument we have that allows us to move toward real competition in the international marketplace in high technology is the Science Council of Canada.
I know that politicians are allowed to fib a little bit, but this government is taking it too far. We were promised that we would have the best programs for replacement due to the free trade agreement and that this government would make every effort to move us into high technology, new areas of job creation and new areas of economic development.
Just like the oceans department, it is now cutting off the Economic Council of Canada.
Who is going to do our research for us in this new Jerusalem it talks about? Nobody. This government is fibbing about its concern for fisheries, as demonstrated by its cutting off the department of oceans.
It is fibbing about its concern about the economic development of this country by cutting off the Economic Council. I believe that this is not an accident. I believe this is part and parcel linked into the total caving in of the Canadian economy to the United States-Canada-Mexico free trade agreement.
The Science Council of Canada is the last one on my list. I said it was stupid. I do not have to prove it, the government is totally stupid. Everything it is doing is stupid. The best thing this government could do is resign before it destroys the product of the best universities that this country has in this question of the Economic Council, the Science Council of Canada.
What is the point of our young children being told to go to university, behave themselves and give something back to Canada if the one instrument we have to give something back to Canada is being cut off? I do not understand this. I try to be charitable. I give choices. I say it is either stupidity or cupidity.
If I thought the government had enough intelligence, I would say it was cupidity. I am left only with stupidity. There are three areas that we need in a highly competitive, global economy, three areas of specific problems here in Canada now, three areas in which this government runs around this country saying it is helping in the fisheries, science and economic development. At the

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
same time, the only instrument they have is being cut off by this government.
With all due respect to the various cabinet ministers and their parliamentary secretaries, who is going to write their answers for them? It is bad enough for this government's ministers to have to stand up in this House and talk inanities that have been written by bureaucrats.
Guess what is going to happen if they have to write their own inanities. They are going to be banal. I could use the word hypocrisy; it is beyond comprehension.
I challenge this government to take its Minister of Fisheries and Oceans into Newfoundland and stand up and explain to the people of Newfoundland why it is cutting off the International Centre for Ocean Development at a time when it is pleading for understanding of overfishing in Newfoundland.
Does the Government of Newfoundland know that it is doing this? Does the Government of Newfoundland approve of this? Not on your life. It is, again, a word that I cannot use: hypocrisy. The International Centre for Ocean Development, the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada are the three instruments that are absolutely essential in terms of this government's own stated-policies being cut off.
The last comment I am going to make is on the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. We have developed a consensus in this country, under the former leadership of the Right Hon. John Diefen-baker, the Right Hon. Lester Pearson and other great leaders of political parties in this House including: M. J. Caldwell, David Lewis and T. C. Douglas, a non-party consensus about Canada's role in international peace and security.
That consensus has never been broken. When people say they are sick and tired of political fighting in this House, the one area in which the political fighting never took place, under Mr. Diefenbaker, Mr. Pearson, Mr. Trudeau, Mr. Douglas, Mr. Lewis and Mr. Caldwell, was a consensus around international peace and security. Why are we destroying that consensus now?
The one thing that makes us international is being destroyed. It is all stupid. I could have started by saying it is stupid, but I will end by saying it is stupid, stupid, stupid.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this bill axing six Crown bodies at a time when Canada needs the direction they provide in terms of leading edge, data analysis and objective input on public policy processes, is nothing short of budgetary vandalism.
The government's motivation for these cuts is purely political, not economic, as it is trying to suggest. I challenge it to do as I have asked of the minister, namely, to justify the cancellation of the Canadian Patents and Development Corporation and the costs that have accrued because of that and the extra staff that had to be hired to allow that work to be carried on within departments.
This is not a surprising move from a government that clearly does not believe in public policy. I have a hard time believing in this government at all. It thinks Parliament is rather irrelevant and is quite prepared to leave everything to the private sector, as the minister said in his budget speech and in his speech introducing the estimates.
By cutting the Science Council, the Economic Council, the Law Reform Commission, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council and the International Centre for Ocean Development, the government is trying to stifle not only the criticisms of its policies by some of the best minds in this country, but what it is really trying to do is stifle criticism from the Reform Party in hopes of gaining back some of the ground it is losing to that new entrant on the political scene.
The Liberal Party, as has been said by a number of our speakers, is not opposed to privatization in principle, but it is certainly opposed to the elimination of valuable bodies that serve a genuine, vital and critical national public policy purpose. It is irresponsible at this time and does not serve the best interests of the country to get rid of bodies that are able to help us as a nation anticipate change, deal with change, see new and emerging opportunities in every area of public policy.
May 4, 1992

Comment and analysis can be seen, as it tends to be seen by this government, as criticism, negative, unproductive, unhelpful to the political position of the party in power. But comment and analysis can be seen as good advice that governments had better pay attention to in developing their new policies and developing their budgetary priorities.
This bill sets up the abolition of bodies that have been capable of bringing together the best minds in Canada to work together on the challenges confronting us; to look at what we are doing, what future directions are globally and where Canada is falling short in achieving the opportunities that are there for us to achieve, whether it is in trade, protection of the environment, greater social justice internally in Canada or wiser use of the resources we have.
What will happen if these works are, as the government says they can be, absorbed into government departments, absorbed into universities? Whether this work gets done will become dependent on whether the government wants it to get done. There is a need for every government to have bodies free to comment, free to analyze, free to advise, regardless of whether the government of the day wants to hear that advice. That is the useful role these bodies have provided.
In a changing world in which the rate of change is increasing so dramatically, we need the ability of people who can stand back from the day-to-day issues and take a longer term view and can predict and help anticipate what is coming next and what are the responses that Canada needs to take to be in the best possible position.
We do not need independent advice that is not "independent". We need to remember, as well, that many of the people who provide services to these bodies do so on an entirely voluntary basis with only their expenses paid. They contribute willingly to the betterment of their nation because they feel the work of these bodies is important. What we do not need is research that is done only because it is research the government wants done. Canadians deserve better than that. They deserve an independent view. Heaven knows, anybody who sits in this House, who sits in committees and who serves his or her constituents knows that we as parliamentarians do not have the time, do not have the expertise, do not have the resources to stand back from our day-to-day work and look longer term at what is
Government Orders
really in the best interests of Canada and its role in the world. We need others to do that for us. We need to benefit from their advice, not to destroy them and cut them off. Nor do we need to cut off and waste the work that is already in progress by many of these agencies.
Can we really expect universities to pick up this kind of research when we know the cutbacks in funding that have occurred to the universities and that continue to occur? What we can really expect is that this valuable work will gradually fall quietly by the wayside.
I want to speak about a couple of particular areas that are of concern to me. I have spoken in this House numerous times on the precarious position in which the sciences and research and technology development in this country find themselves. The government is abolishing the Science Council at a time when the world knows that knowledge is the new commodity for nations in the world. The Science Council can help us plan how to develop that knowledge, how to become the best in the world and how to identify areas in which Canada can have a particular expertise. The cancellation of a body like this at this point in time is nothing short of sheer stupidity.
How can one possibly think that we can compete in the world of the future if we do not look at all areas of development of new knowledge that will allow Canada to establish specialized niches in the international economy?
I will give you a few examples of where the Science Council has spoken: areas of water supply, a key issue for Canada and a key issue for the world; areas of technology for cold regions. What better country than Canada to focus on technology for cold regions and all the economic opportunities that offers.
I want to speak on one other agency and that is the International Centre for Ocean Development. One of the major environmental issues in the very near future will be the availability of water and the availability of food. The International Centre for Ocean Development is doing a number of things. It is cutting the research and the transmission of knowledge to developing countries as to how they can better use ocean resources for food at a time when the scarcity of food is a major international crisis, as well as the potential scarcity and damage to water. Not only that, this centre offers the opportunity to be the base for regional development in Atlantic Canada by focusing on the strengths of that region. That is the

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
kind of regional development that is going to help all parts of our country share fully in the wealth of Canada.
These cuts are arbitrary and irresponsible. These organizations are crucial to Canada as we plan our future and plan to take full advantage of the potential that is there for us both nationally and internationally.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a sad
day for this House and for Canadians when the government axes so many programs without public debate, without bringing before Canadians the reasons why each one of those agencies or bodies, which has served Canada in the past, is no longer appropriate to meet the needs of Canadians.
We on this side of the House are not against cost cutting, cost cutting that makes sense, cost cutting where an agency or board or tribunal no longer serves a purpose, where it is outdated. We are not against sunsets i.e., that would mean that the life of a board or group would terminate automatically after say, five or ten years subject to debate, debate by the representatives of the people of Canada as to whether that board or agency is fulfilling its function or purpose.
We can achieve effective cost cutting if we as parliamentarians have the opportunity to scrutinize in detail what is being done. This is not the case with this Draconian bill that has been brought before Parliament.
I cite just one example for the time being, the Science Council of Canada. Here is a body that has served Canada extremely well in the past. It has run a lean operation. The total cost was just slightly over $3 million a year. What is more important, this is an independent agency reporting not to the bureaucracy, not to the Prime Minister, but to Parliament. Its obligation is to the people of Canada at large through their elected representatives.
Have we heard one good reason put forward why the Science Council of Canada is no longer serving the needs of Canada? Surely it cannot be the stack of reports that it has published. Surely it cannot be the work which it has on an ongoing continuum, dealing with competitiveness, dealing with training, dealing with some of the most important issues in our society: economic issues, issues which strike at the ability of young Canadians to have
jobs in the future, of Canadians to keep their jobs. Some $3 million was the council's budget.
I have a serious disagreement with the minister of science and technology who approved the axing of this agency. I say with respect to the hon. gentleman, I know that it was not his decision to cut the Science Council because his whole past record speaks of his commitment to science and technology in Canada.
What is unfortunate is that he lost out at the cabinet table. When I talked to him about this in committee, I know he was embarrassed. I asked him: "Minister, would you rather have one prosperity agenda costing over $20 million or would you rather have six science councils of Canada for the same cost?" He could not answer that question satisfactorily. It was an embarrassing question for him.
What do we have to replace the Science Council to give independent advice to Parliament? There is nothing. We have perhaps another body called NAB ST whose members are chosen by the Prime Minister, which reports directly to the Prime Minister and which is not going to be particularly critical of government policies. How are Canadians better served by having a body that reports to the Prime Minister as opposed to Parliament?
The beauty of the Science Council of Canada was that it served as an independent voice for science and technology in Canada. It was universally supported by the scientific community of Canada. What this body dared to do was criticize the government for its cutbacks to science and technology, for its cutbacks to the Science Council itself, for its cutbacks to the National Research Council.
I compare what the chairperson of the Science Council did to what the chairperson for the National Research Council did when they came before our committees. When I asked the head of the NRC if he felt that his role as the head of the most important publicly funded research body in Canada was to speak as an independent voice for science and technology in Canada, he refused to answer that question. I said: "Do you consider your role to be that of a toady for the government?" He said he was insulted. I said: "Let me put the question in another way. Do you feel that you will criticize openly cutbacks to your own body, the National Research Council?" He said: "No, I will not do that". I said: "Mr. Chairman, the head of the NRC has just answered my
May 4, 1992

question as to what he considers his role to be: a toady for the government".
This is not the case with the Science Council of Canada. The chairperson came before us and talked about the importance of a decent level of funding for science and technology in Canada. The over-all level of research and development has continually fallen since the Conservative government took office eight years ago. We all remember the promise of the Prime Minister when he said: "This government in four years will double Canada's research and development. We will take it from 1.4 per cent of gross domestic product to over 2.5 per cent".
Why did he promise that? Because he knew that unless Canada did that we would not keep up with the competitive nature of the world community. All of our major economic competitors have levels of R and D which exceed 2 per cent, more than double ours.
Since that commitment, that promise was made to Canadians, the Prime Minister has presided over a government that has seen R and D in Canada actually fall as a percentage of our gross domestic product. No wonder we are facing very severe economic times in this country, more severe than in most of our OECD competitors.
Where is the long-term strategic thinking? Where are we going to get the innovation, the technology, the inventions that are going to provide our young Canadians with the stimulating jobs and the platform from which they can launch the new industries, the biotechnologies, the aerospaces, the computer software and everything else.
We need bodies like the Science Council of Canada. If you asked any of the ministers of industry from any country in the west what are the keys to the economic future of their country, they would say training, research, development, education. Research and development, science and technology, are right at the forefront of every type of remedy for a sagging economy. Even this government pays lip-service to it, but what does it do? It cuts the one body which has provided that type of independent voice in Canada, a voice which in the past has dared to criticize this government, a voice which has
Government Orders
dared to be strong, to be non-political and to give us the prescriptions we need.
I see across the House from me the former chairperson of the industry, science and technology committee. That chairperson knew at the time that the Science Council of Canada was one of the most credible bodies that appeared before us. She was the chairperson when our committee issued a unanimous report calling for increases in research and development in Canada, a commitment to double it by the year 2000. We expressed our support unanimously for the Science Council of Canada. Where is her voice now saying: "Minister, you cannot allow this to be cut; it was a unanimous committee report that I chaired, that I authored". Have we heard her speak up against this?
I asked the minister if he would go back to cabinet and help us.
Mr. Speaker, I know my time has run out. This is a sad day for Canada's future. We must oppose this bill.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today we are dealing with a number of agencies that will be either wound up or deferred, merged or privatized. But I want to spend a few minutes talking about one of the agencies which will be deferred.
That is the Canadian Race Relations Foundation. As you know, Mr. Speaker, the regrettable incidents in Los Angeles of a few days back remind us of how fortunate we are to live in such a magnificent society. I, for one, am very fortunate to have in my riding the head office of the Ottawa police force. Thanks to the leadership of Chief Tom Flanagan and the efforts of his highly qualified officers, the Ottawa police force has established excellent relations with the community. The Ottawa police force has established community liaison offices, developed school education outreach programs, supported community initiatives, and developed a first-class reputation in the protection of life and the law.
Legislation dealing with the Canadian Race Relations Foundation was introduced last year and approved with the hope that the government would proceed. Unfortunately, it was deferred. It is my hope that in light of all of those unfortunate events taking place around the globe that at least in Canada we see the positive things that

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
could come out as a result of such a foundation and that the government will not at this point in time defer it but will proceed.
While not every agency in existence performs the duties and responsibilities that the Ottawa police force does, I wanted to mention it while I talk about the deferral of the foundation. I believe it is very important for my community , which is extremely diverse, to know how fortunate we are to have a police force that is sensible and sensitive to our needs and wishes.
The legislation before us deals in particular with the winding down of a number of agencies, commissions, and councils.
I begin with the Science Council that the government is planning to wind down. As you know, since 1967 until recently, this council has recommended a number of initiatives and has helped in the creation of many agencies such as the Canadian Space Agency. It has done many things in the community when it comes to the well-being of Canadians. For example, it has urged Canadians to recycle. It has been on top of many of the issues when it comes to sustainable development, in particular, when we talk about sustainable agriculture as well as water supply.
More than anything, the world is moving ahead. The Science Council has seen an opportunity in the biotechnology industiy. It has done a tremendous amount of work in advising both the government as well as the community as a whole on the importance of biotechnology to the well-being of Canada.
The Science Council has played a leadership role on every front providing unbiased advice to both governments and agencies in the community. We are seeing this council being wound up. For the life of me, I cannot see how the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology can allow such a thing to go down without a fight.
I want to say publicly if the minister sees there is any possibility whatsoever between now and the time this legislation goes to the Senate that the opposition could be of any help, he should call on us and we will be on with this.
Another initiative deals with the Economic Council. We just recently saw a tremendous report come out of the Economic Council that deals with the question of
education and illiteracy in Canada. I cannot tell you how dead-on the Economic Council was in its report.
I would suggest the government rather than winding up this council should do the opposite. It should enhance the council's viability. It should support the council with more manpower and resources so it can continue the tremendous good work it has been doing from 1963 until now.
The Law Reform Commission is another commission the government is planning to close down. This commission was introduced in 1970. In over 22 years it has produced in excess of 32 reports and 61 working papers. It has also produced 76 studies containing recommendations covering Criminal Code reform, hate propaganda, plea bargaining, safeguarding genetic heritage, pornography, arson, sexual assault, mental disorder and many other subjects. As of 1990 commission studies have been cited in at least of 211 reported Canadian court decisions, 39 of which were Supreme Court of Canada decisions.
To terminate the Court Challenges Program in my view is a crime. Simply put, trying to obtain justice in our society has become extremely difficult. It has become one of the things that only the well-to-do and the rich can obtain in a fair and equitable way. It is my hope the day will come when we see justice done for everybody in equality, without the dependency on the ability to pay.
Another fine institution is the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. Between 1984 and 1992 it established a research and information library, developed school education curriculum programs, supported Canadian scholars and in general developed a first-class centre for peace and security offering a Canadian perspective. Right now is the opportune time for the government to enhance and support the work of the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
Our world is going through turbulent times. Take for example eastern Europe. Unless we see peace and security in Yugoslavia in the next few months, the world is going to see the beginning of something that none of us will like. Not just Europe, but the whole world will find itself in a volcanic situation. For us as a country that has spoken out so forcefully on issues that affect the peace and security of the world, it is unfair to turn

around and fold up or wind down one of the finest institutions that can continue to bring Canadians pride.
Those are some of the agencies that are going to be wound up, much of whose work is unknown to anyone who could continue that work. For instance, many of these agencies have work plans for the next five years. It is beyond me to see the government winding down those organizations without providing an effective alternative or without doing a study or analysis to find out about the viability of those organizations.
We on this side of the House believe that these organizations should not be wound up. They should be maintained and enhanced. I ask you, Mr. Speaker, to call on the government to reverse its decision and not close down these organizations.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I find myself so often standing and speaking in the House of Commons with regret because of the subject matter under debate. I pray for the day when one can stand up with pride about the legislation presented because it is so positive and far-reaching and has some hope for this country which we love so much.
I was rather intrigued this morning when listening to the debate. One of the government members stood up and said it is not the job of the government to employ people. It is the government's job to provide the climate where the private sector can thrive and employ people. That may possibly be. Mr. Speaker, I will tell you something. It is not working. Therein lies the problem.
This government depends on the private sector and because of that this country is in a state of dependency on something that does not work. There is no hope for the economic outlook of Canada at all with the dependence on monetarism and supply side economics.
The other day, I read an article by an American economist from the supply side who actually admitted it. He said that supply side never really was an economic theory. It was only a way of describing and obfuscating the economic situation in order that Ronald Reagan would be able to put forth his ideas and to enable the
Government Orders
wealthy to become even more wealthy. The trickle down theory is what it is. It is also, of course, what is behind the Canadian situation, where we have free trade, whether it is the FTA or the NAFTA and Heaven knows what other free trade agreement the government is liable to come up with next.
However, this philosophy is the source of the tremendous debt in this country of ours. The debt created by this government, created by its misled, misdirected economic philosophy is what has led us to the impasse we have reached. It is, of course, the excuse for bringing in Bill C-63. Everything this government does by way of trying to make the Canadian public think it is saving the taxpayer money is done under the excuse that we have such an enormous debt.
It has not been all that broadly stated, except that the clue to the underlying rationale or excuse which this government came up with was stated by the member this morning when he said that it was not the government's job to employ people. Of course, the debt is not the real reason for it. The debt is the excuse for doing it. What the government really wants to do is to kill the messenger and we have several messengers within the organizations this government is slashing under Bill C-63. There are several messengers who often provide rather bad news to the government. It is the government's intention to try to silence these voices as much as possible.
In almost every Question Period through which I have sat since I was elected to the House of Commons, the finance minister or the Prime Minister or some minister of the government has said that if this country is going to be prosperous, if this country is going to compete, if this government is going to be able to fulfil its destiny not only in the remaining decade of this century but also into the 21st century and become the country it is supposed to be, then we have to educate our children, we have to train our children, we have to give our citizens every opportunity to become as well trained and technologically advanced as is possible.
Then we have this proposal in Bill C-63. Can there be any doubt that regardless of what the Canadian public says, regardless of what our universities say, or our institutes of post-secondary learning say, that the

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
Science Council of Canada is going to be eliminated? Can you believe that?
The council over the years has provided at times bad news to the government. I would suggest it is certainly part of the function of the Science Council of Canada to point out to the government where it is making mistakes. Why else would it be there if it is not to adjudge what is happening in this country as far as the advancement of science and technology is concerned?
Sometimes it is conceivable that governments are not necessarily on the right track. I would suggest that it is certainly within the purview of a council such as the Science Council of Canada to let the government know. Obviously the government has seen the Science Council of Canada as a bearer of bad news and is certainly going to kill the messenger.
I was rather interested in some earlier rationale. It may have been part of the budget debate when the Minister of Finance was criticized for getting rid of the Economic Council of Canada and other bodies which the government is eliminating as well, the comeback was that these services could be provided within the private sector. Therein lies the problem, particularly if we are talking in terms of the elimination of the Economic Council of Canada.
One of the previous speakers asked: "If the Economic Council of Canada cannot provide the government with the valuable information which it has over the years, who will?" I would disagree with my learned colleague from Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca who said nobody.
I would suggest that the government is quite able to find within the private sector a substitute for the Economic Council of Canada. I would guess by the economic philosophy it has so conscientiously followed ever since it came into office that it has not been paying enough attention to the Economic Council of Canada but has certainly embraced the Fraser Institute. The musings- and I think they cannot be much more than that-of the Fraser Institute although they have had devastating effects on the country are what the government has been following.
I suppose there are substitutes within the private sector which can take over from some of these boards and commissions. That does not necessarily mean it is
good news for the people of Canada. Perhaps the people of Canada should be the ones who get rid of the messenger in this case. I would suggest that is going to occur before too long.
Other institutions are going to be eliminated which have served this country very well, such as the Canadian Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. We as citizens and we as parliamentarians are rather proud of our immigration policy. Perhaps we should ask ourselves why Canada has had such a good immigration policy, why we have shown so much compassion.
I see you indicating, Mr. Speaker, that my time is coming to a close. There is certainly not enough time to address all the institutes which are going to be eliminated. However, I would suggest that perhaps one of the main reasons Canada has had such a good policy as far as immigration is concerned is that very council. Its elimination is certainly not going to enhance Canada's image and the advice it gives to the Canadian government. It is not going to enhance the government's ability to deal adequately with the immigration concerns which we will be having in the future.
I have not been able to address all the issues. I thank the House for giving me the time it has. Perhaps we can pursue the issue at a later date.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when hon. members heard the Minister of Finance say in his budget speech that he intended to get rid of a number of government agencies, many of us were astonished the government wanted to eliminate agencies that provided the government with non-partisan advice, advice that may not always have been what we wanted to hear as parliamentarians, but advice that was extremely valuable just the same.
Let me give an example. The job of the Economic Council of Canada was not called "the tell the government what it wants to hear council of Canada", it was called the Economic Council of Canada. Obviously its job was to provide to all of us as MPs and to the Canadian public expert advice on economic matters.
May 4, 1992

As one member said earlier, some private sector organizations do that now, but is it the role of these organizations to provide independent advice to the benefit of everyone or advice which will benefit their own members?
Earlier today I received a very thick and glossy brochure. I guess it must have had about 75 pages to it, possibly even more, from Thomas d'Aquino and those other fine people at the Business Council on National Issues. St. Thomas d'Aquino gave us all his usual very excellent advice, at least the advice that he wants to convey on behalf of his members. That may very well be the view of the members that he represents or purports to represent, but is it to the best interest of the Canadian public?
On the other side, some groups will advocate measures which they feel will better groups at the other end. They could be organizations that represent organized labour or what have you, but who speaks for everyone? Who provides independent advice to all of us in economic matters and that advice being unbiased and in everyone's interest?
I submit to you, Mr. Speaker, that that was one of the jobs of the Economic Council of Canada.

Unfortunately, the council is now doomed to disappear because of the Minister of Finance's budget.
Interestingly, in Bill C-63 the government not only proposes to wind down the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council, and so forth, it even wants to eliminate any reference to these agencies in our legislation, like someone who tears up the photograph of a husband or wife to wipe out every trace, every memory of the past, memories that would otherwise come back to haunt the Conservatives, memories of the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council and many others.

If you think that I am the only one who feels that way about some of these organizations, let me read a little bit here from a story written by Stephen Bindman who is an excellent writer for The Ottawa Citizen. He is actually a writer for Southam News but Southam of course distrib-
Govemment Orders
utes articles to such papers as The Ottawa Citizen. Listen to this statement:
When the Law Reform Commission of Canada winds down over the next three months Canada will join Zimbabwe and Bangladesh as the only Commonwealth countries without an independent Law Reform Commission.
That is where this government has brought us. That is where the Prime Minister has brought us. Not according to the hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell or the hon. member for Hamilton Mountain, although I am sure she could provide equally objective and constructive comments in this House this afternoon, but according to the Canadian Bar Association as reported in this Southam story for The Ottawa Citizen. We have now joined the ranks of Zimbabwe and Bangladesh in terms of not having an independent Law Reform Commission.
Some months ago a number of members of this Parliament were debating a bill, and a horrible bill it was by the way, Bill C-203 which was kind of a euthanasia bill. It is still debatable as to what that thing was.
In any case, we were debating that bill. Some of the advice that we received was from the Law Reform Commission, not that we had asked it to present something to us but we were relying on many of the things that it had said in the past on this issue. We looked for its counsel. We sought information that was written in that regard by the Law Reform Commission.
On many of the issues discussed in courts, as has been indicated by the hon. member for Ottawa Centre, cases have utilized time and time again briefs, papers, documents of the Law Reform Commission of Canada, as it should be. We should have that kind of independent legal advice to make sure that we remain a country which believes and which advocates the enhancement and protection of the democratic rights of everyone.
We saw a great country last week tearing itself apart to a certain measure on racial issues: the United States of America. When we saw what happened in Los Angeles and other cities in which we saw that violence, we saw a judicial system which had failed in my opinion and failed miserably. Here we are in Canada, not that it is perfect, far from it, but we have at least some of the tools that have made this country better. It could be a lot better yet, granted.
Here we are dismantling some of those tools right now, as we speak today in the House of Commons on May 4, 1992. I ask: Why are we doing this? Why are we

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
abolishing the Law Reform Commission of Canada? Why are we abolishing the Economic Council of Canada?
I can only conclude one thing, that these organizations were telling this government many things that the government did not want to hear. The Economic Council of Canada prepared a report which was made public last week and from which members quoted extensively in this Elouse. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to say a word about the Law Reform Commission first, which the government is destroying in this bill.
We have about six items in this bill that the government is putting out of existence. They are very important to the parliamentary history of Canada.
There is one thing that bothers me particularly as I look at the Law Reform Commission proposal. It is really a wind-up of that commission, as the previous speaker stated. It also states that the Department of Justice will contract out for research and publish reports directly.
There is a secret agenda here. Contracting out is the key. More jobs for Tory friends. That is what is going to happen. It is going to be more contracting out. We have just seen in the Public Service reform bill that the merit principle is going to be taken away in the Public Service of Canada and there is going to be work contracted out. The contracting out will go to people who want to report what the government wants to hear.
All of these six commissions and bodies that we are talking about today are independent bodies that have tabled their information in this House through the appropriate minister. The government is very upset because the government has been left empty-handed with some of these reports because these reports have flown in the face of what the government is doing.

We must not forget the 300 jobs that will be lost. Many of my constituents in the national capital region are employed by these agencies. However, more than that will be lost. By dismantling something that later will cost millions of dollars to rebuild, we will lose the expertise, because those experts will be scattered across Canada and perhaps beyond, and we will have trouble rebuilding later what this government now proposes to wind down.
I want to ask all my colleagues on the other side of the House to for once take the objective view and prevent this government from terminating the various agencies I just mentioned.
We who are in this House day after day can understand why government wants to get rid of these bodies that are going to give it some good advice. We in the opposition and other members talk in this House from day to day about what should be done and what should not be done. Yet nobody is listening. Government does not want to listen to these bodies either because it has its own agenda.
Under the mandate of the Law Reform Commission it undertakes some research in-house, contracts out other work to consultants on a full or part-time basis. That is a conflict in terms. At the same time as you are contracting out, you are indeed not listening to the very people
.
May 4, 1992

whom you are appointing to these commissions and who are there because of their expertise.
Let's take a look at the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. What is the proposal here? To wind it up, for the Department of External Affairs to take over functions as appropriate. This body was established in 1984 under its own act of Parliament and the Secretary of State for External Affairs designated as the responsible minister. That minister is the one who has been tabling this report in the House of Commons.
One can understand, and one must ask the question: Is there competition between the bureaucrats in External Affairs who are jealous of their advice to the Secretary of State for External Affairs and what the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security might provide as information for the minister?
In other words, here again we are taking away the valued opinions of people who are professionals in their field to advise a government that does not want to be advised because it has its own agenda.
The mandate of the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security was to increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relating to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective, with particular emphasis on arms control, disarmament, defence and conflict resolution.
What could be more appropriate than to have this Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security advising a government of a country that has probably participated more than any other country in the world in international affairs in the area of peacekeeping and keeping hot spots in the world cooled off?
I was in this House when this bill was passed in Parliament.
We had great hopes at that time, I remember, for good research being done on the issues around the world. Before you go into an international crisis, you had better understand what the background is and what is going on and who all the players are, not only who some of them are. The institute was one that did considerable studies, in-depth studies, on these international issues.
Here is Canada, a country that does a great deal of good work around the world in peacekeeping and working with other nations in a diplomatic manner in order to bring hot spots to a cooling off position and to restore
Government Orders
peace and prevent these things from spreading into a major war. That is Canada's role.
The government should be ashamed of itself today for bringing in this bill which destroys the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security while at the same time bragging about what Canadians do in peacekeeping around the world. This government today cannot hold a candle to the late Right Hon. Lester B. Pearson, the late Right Hon. Louis St-Laurent and the Right Hon. Pierre Elliott Trudeau and others for what they have done in peacekeeping of this country with the international community. I would add the Hon. Mitchell Sharp to that list as well.
If Canada is going to continue to play a role in keeping the peace of the world, in carrying on good diplomatic relations with countries around the world, we need this kind of research. You do not go into a war disarmed of what it is all about. You have to have knowledge as well as your equipment. If you have knowledge beforehand, you may not need the equipment. I think this is something that the government has totally overlooked.
I would like to say that the Science Council of Canada has been a tremendous body in this nation since its establishment in 1966. I was in the House when the bill was passed. It was established in 1966 by the Science Council of Canada Act. It was a departmental corporation reporting to Parliament through the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and to whomever was delegated authority as the minister in charge of science.
What could be more important in this day and age when we are talking about competitiveness? This government is in conflict with itself. Out of one side of its mouth its says we have to be competitive and we are going to match the world and out of the other side, it is doing away with the very bodies by Bill C-63 today such as the Science Council of Canada, which is one of the six. It is doing away with the very body. If the government were willing to take its advice, follow its recommendations, Canada would be on top of the heap and we would not be in the economic mess we are in today.
It is hard to assess this government. No one knows where it is coming from. What is the mandate of the Science Council of Canada? So that all Canadians will understand, here it is. It is there to assess scientific and technological resources, requirements and potentialities for Canada and to increase public awareness of scientific and technological problems as well as opportunities. What is more important than that when it comes to

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
competition with other countries? It undertakes research, publishes studies and reports and provides advice to the minister.
The latter is a problem. The minister does not want to be bothered taking advice. Neither does the government.
Finally, concerning the Economic Council of Canada, in this day and age when this country is facing such horrendous unemployment line-ups, disasters, industries are closing down and moving out, small business is in trouble, what does the Economic Council of Canada do? subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today we are debating Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies.
The budget announcement last February highlighted the elimination of some 46 government agencies. Twelve hundred federal employees would be affected, 500 jobs lost, and all for a savings of some $22 million.
With one simple swing of the henchman's axe, this government has served to silence the valued advice of advisory boards which have served this government and previous governments for decades. It is a senseless, stupid piece of legislation. It serves no rational purpose other than the fact that this government simply wishes to silence its critics and kill the messenger.
Simply, it does not like getting advice, the advice that has been given in good faith by these organizations
through the many years they have served both the government and the people of Canada.
It is a method of simply muffling the criticisms that have been brought before this government in terms of the government's own failure to address the many concerns that these individual councils and organizations have highlighted.
It is also a piece of legislation that is unbelievably arrogant. It is arrogant because what it is saying, what the government is saying to the people of Canada, is that it knows better. It does not need the advice of these organizations and professional bodies that have served through the years because it has all the answers. That is what this bill is saying. The government does not want to listen to the valued advice of these agencies because it knows all the answers.
Heaven knows that the people of Canada firmly believe that this government does not have all the answers.
That is why this piece of legislation is so incredibly arrogant. It is arrogant for the government to think that it knows better and can dispense with these boards, with these organizations, with these agencies, that it can simply do away with them because it does not like to hear the bad news. It is simply unbelievable.
Let us look at six very critical agencies that have served for many years: the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council; the Law Reform Commission; the Institute for International Peace and Security; the Economic Council of Canada; the International Centre for Ocean Developments; the Science Council of Canada. These six organizations have provided through the years extremely valuable information, service and advice that this government has largely chosen not to act upon, that it has chosen to ignore.
I get the feeling that the government has been feeling the heat because many of these organizations have been critical at times of the policies and the direction that this government has followed. Rather than take the heat and admit its mistakes and failures, the government has simply chosen to kill the messenger, to silence the criticisms. It is dumb. It is stupid. It is simply outrageous. This legislation will do nothing but harm the process of
May 4, 1992

valued advice that this government should be and hopefully would be open to.
When you look at it in large measure, it is in line with the government's over-all plan to reduce services. What is even more frightening is that it is very much in line with what can only be called the corporate agenda.
The Business Council on National Issues, headlined by his royal highness, Thomas d'Aquino, is really the agency that is pulling the strings and the government has merely been its mouthpiece. It said: "jump", and this government has asked: "How high?" It said: "cut services" and this government asked, "how deep?" It is all part and parcel of this corporate agenda for Canada of which the people of Canada, I might add, are growing weary. There is no rational explanation for the silencing of these advisory boards.
In particular, let us have a look at the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. This organization provided advice to those people who were affected by this government's employment and immigration policies. There was too much criticism so it simply silenced it with one fell swoop of the axe.
Regarding the Law Reform Commission, it had 20 years of service to the Minister of Justice. It provided a review of the statutes of Canada and made a series of very valid recommendations for the improvement of particular statutes and for the reform of common law in Canada. It cost $4.9 million a year for this organization to function-too expensive; kill it, turf it out, get rid of it.
The Economic Council of Canada is another 20-year institution that has been silenced by this government. The objective was to provide advice on how to achieve the highest possible levels of employment in Canada. It was a very influential and a very prestigious think-tank that has been highly regarded across this country. It prepared reports throughout the years on education, health care, productivity, employment and on retraining programs. Absolutely no warning was given when the government decided to kill this organization and to silence yet another voice of criticism. It was a ham-fisted, totally arrogant approach. This government is facing the worst unemployment crisis this country has seen in many, many years and it silences the very
Government Orders
advisory board that is trying to develop the policies and initiatives to get us out of the difficult situation we face.
One that strikes particularly close to home is the Science Council of Canada, another organization, 25 years old, that has given service to this administration and previous administrations in Canada. It had the important task of assessing scientific and technological resources and potentials in Canada and holding the government to task on its performance in terms of developing research and development initiatives in Canada.
Throughout the years the council at times has provided very strong criticism of this government. It has even embarrassed this government. It has reminded this government of how it has abandoned its previous commitment to increase basic research and development in Canada. What has the government done? It has taken the axe and silenced yet another criticism.
It talks about globalization, it talks about the need for international competitiveness. Therefore, it has eliminated the Science of Council of Canada and has done a great, great disservice to scientists across this country as well as to our aspiring students of science from Victoria to St. John's.

Right here in Canada we face a very critical problem. Our own northern cod stocks off Newfoundland have been devastated by the overfishing of other countries off

the Grand Banks. What is the government's response to this crisis? It silences another messenger.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, behind a very harmless looking title, namely an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies, there is a measure of enormous importance we are debating today.
Bill C-63, I submit to you, is a bad measure. It is wrong. It is a wrong proposal by the government. I am saying that because the government is disbanding centres of excellence which have served Canadians well. People with unique skills are being laid off because the Government of Canada says we do not need advice anymore. These are the people who have given Canada creative ideas, who have pointed at new opportunities, who have measured performance in the country, who have told Canadians of how and when we were doing well and when we were doing badly and have advised the government of the day accordingly.
It was extremely disturbing to have learned of this measure we are debating today as we did on February 25 when the Minister of Finance announced his budget. This measure can only come into effect once this bill has passed. This government is labouring under the illusion that it knows better, it needs no advice, it has all the answers.
In other words, the Minister of Finance will from now on perform the role of some of the major councils that are being abolished by this bill. The Minister of Finance will be the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security and the Centre for Ocean Development just to name a few. That is now the role the Minister of Finance has implicitly assumed for himself.
People not in politics expressed their shock when they heard of this dreadful decision. Nobel prize winner, John Polanyi, commented in Toronto: "In our concern that the ship of state is too big, we are removing the rudder". That is how John Polanyi put it.
I am glad to see in the House the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology. He knows of the calibre of John
Polanyi who is a distinguished Canadian and a Nobel prize winner. Dr. Polanyi said "in our concern that the ship of state is too big" because that was the argument of the Minister of Finance on February 25. He wanted efficiency and in the name of efficiency we are cutting the rudder. That is the logic and the principle this government is pursuing with this measure. This is unacceptable, obscene and just unbelievably stupid.
Dr. Polanyi went on to say: "It is vital to have a body that is thinking about the future of science and technology in this country". We are then to believe that with the removal of the Science Council of Canada the minister will do all the thinking for it. If he cannot, then the Minister of Finance will do it for the Science Council. That is the logic behind this measure.
Dr. Polanyi went on to say that every industrial country that is ambitious has to have a science and technology organization at arm's length from the government so it can be critical and so it can see past this year's crisis. It is so elementary, so basic, that one cannot understand how this has escaped the collective brains of the cabinet of this government.
Let us move to the Economic Council of Canada and put on record what the distinguished analyst, David Crane, wrote in The Toronto Star last February.
He wrote that the Minister of Finance's decision means that the Department of Finance and the Bank of Canada will no longer have to put up with the Economic Council casting doubt on a monetary policy that keeps 1.5 million Canadians unemployed, nor will they have to tolerate the council criticizing the lack of effort in worker training, calling for reform in agricultural policy or making inconvenient policy proposals to improve competitiveness.
The only losers are Canadians who want an informed debate in Canada. That is the last thing the Minister of Finance and his cabinet colleagues want but this should be no surprise. Since the Mulroney government came into office, there has been a continuous series of steps to restrict the flow of information. One of the first was the decision to make each report from Statistics Canada self-financing.
The Minister of Finance is one of those hard-edged politicians who is intrinsically hostile to public debate unless it can be carefully controlled. That is why he is prepared to spend more than $20 million on a vacuous
May 4, 1992

public relations gimmick known as the prosperity initiative.
While it cancels all these bodies, at the same time it can find the money for this public relations gimmick, the prosperity initiative. But he cannot support the continuation of these councils holding meetings, running lots of advertising to promote competitiveness while at the same time claiming that Canada cannot afford the $3.25 million for the Science Council or the $11 million for the Economic Council. What a sham.
What we have is a shabby decision which appeals to the Tory right wing with no alternative ideas around, of course. Canada will be the loser. Canada will be the loser because a strong democracy depends on both solid information and the range of policy ideas being available to the public. That is what a good, strong, healthy democracy depends on.
Let us now look at the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security as in the case of the Economic Council and the Science Council. This is the most inopportune time to kill the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
Eastern Europe is in turmoil. Parts of Africa are facing famine and environmental degradation. Outdated and faulty nuclear power stations all over the place are threatening security with the potential for new Chemo-byls. Yugoslavia has fallen apart.
This is not the time to do that. It does not make sense. It is backward. It is idiotic. It is stupid. I am running out of adjectives.
Massachusetts Institute of Technology Professor Lincoln Bloomfield, certainly not a Liberal, certainly not a Canadian, arguing that Canada has become a focal point for research and knowledge about international security said that the government's decision will "give a powerful, negative message to the world about Canada's role in this new era where Canadian leadership is more essential than ever".
I am told that the institute is obligated under law to continue its functions until Parliament passes legislation to dismantle it and Treasury Board is committed to continue providing money to finance it. For the sake of peace and security in the world, it may be a good move to prolong this debate for as long as we can.
Government Orders
In The Ottawa Citizen editorial of March 7, under the title "Lobotomizing Canada's future":
The Mulroney government has been accused before of not
knowing where it is going. Now it apparently has decided it doesn't
want to know even where it should be going.
We did not write that editorial. It went on to say:
A long-range, independent view in economic and science policy is
essential to Canada's prosperity.
The swan-song of the Economic Council of Canada is titled: "A Lot to Learn". It is a report on education and training in Canada. Yes, this is the last one that we are going to see on such an essential subject.
We have seen many reports: "Crimes Against the Environment" from the Law Reform Commission; "Pulling Together-Productivity, Innovation and Trade" by the Economic Council; "The Canadian Agricultural Policy and Prairie Agriculture"; "Climate Change-Global Security and International Governments"; "Sustainable Farming-Possibilities Between 1990 and 2020," a discussion paper by the Science Council of Canada; "A Protected Areas Vision for Canada" by CEAC, the Canadian Environmental Advisory Council. The list is very long.
We will never again see the likes of it because of this backward, primitive, non-understandable, idiotic decision by this government. It is unbearable that the public interest be mutilated, amputated and so gravely damaged by such a decision of the Minister of Finance with the budget on February 25.
Mr. Speaker, I wish I had another half hour to go on.
