speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to speak on this bill this afternoon.
I would like to follow up on the excellent speech by the member for Davenport. As he has expressed, I am completely disgusted and mystified by the government's decision to do away with these organizations.
As the member has said, the Economic Council has been a source of pride for this country. Its most recent report on education is something which every Canadian should read. Therein lies our future competitiveness, therein lies the future of our young people and where we

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
are going as a nation. It is absolutely incredible that the government would do away with this organization.
The Science Council of Canada is another excellent organization which has been tremendous for this country. If only it had been listened to, we would have gotten so much more out of it.
A friend of mine was in Japan when the news that the government was cancelling the Science Council of Canada became public. He said that the Japanese were completely mystified as to why the Canadian government would cancel this tremendous organization. He could not understand at this time of global competitiveness that Canada, a country which is at the end of the spectrum except for Italy as far as R and D expenditure per capita is concerned, would not only not be making strides to increase its research and development, but would actually be going out and cancelling an important organization for the future of Canada like the Science Council of Canada.
In the time I have remaining I want to speak about the Law Reform Commission. As justice critic for my party I am completely shocked and saddened that the government would decide to do away with this very important organization. It has been at the foundation of new legal thinking in our country.
We only have to look to the situation in Los Angeles to see that we can never take for granted the evolution of our justice system and the evolution of crime control in our communities. We can never take for granted that we have the question of law and order under control, that our legal system is fine for the future because as our society evolves, our legal system must also evolve.
The Law Reform Commission was founded in 1971. Last year it had a budget of $4.8 million. That is a sizeable amount of money, but I want to give more of an idea of the importance of the spending of that money.
The work of the Law Reform Commission has been cited in 255 court decisions, including 44 decisions of the Supreme Court of Canada. People come to you and say: "How many of the ideas of the Law Reform Commission are now law? How many of the reports have been put into statute?" That is a complete red herring. Anybody who would say that is a complete Philistine as far as evolution of the law is concerned. In the reports and the
thinking of the Law Reform Commission are ideas which have come forward for the future and the evolution of our society, our law reform, law and order and the proper progress of our legal system.
We have had these reports and these ideas cited in 255 of our court decisions, 44 of the decisions of the Supreme Court of Canada. Most recently, we have had decisions come forward that are now part of Bill C-46, the contraventions bill, which we are going to be debating in this House tomorrow. The Law Reform Commission came forward with the idea. That is the backbone of the contraventions bill, C-46. The Law Reform Commission came forward with that idea in 1976, sixteen years ago. Only now is this government putting these ideas into force.
It gives you an idea of the forward thinking of the Law Reform Commission. The government says it does not need the Law Reform Commission. The Department of Justice can take the place of the Law Reform Commission. That is not only a pathetic thought, it is a scaiy thought. It is a scary thought because right now you have the most retrogressive thinking in the Department of Justice we have had in this country in many, many years. It is so busy playing catch-up to what it feels it has to do that it is not even close at being the vanguard of legal thinking in this country. It is completely consumed with politics, completely consumed with damage control. For the minister and the government to say that this is the department that should be at the forefront of new legal concepts in developing the evolution of our legal system is absolute and complete ridiculousness. As I have said, that is a very frightening proposal for the government to make.
I will give another statistic that will put the Neanderthal thinking of this government in perspective. By doing away with our Law Reform Commission in Canada, we now join Zimbabwe and Bangladesh as the only three countries in the Commonwealth that do not have a law reform commission. We are not progressing in legal thought in this country. We are sliding backward. We are cascading backward in the very retrogressive and reactionary thinking of this government. We cannot possibly allow this to happen. The Department of Justice is prosecuting. It is prosecutorial. It is reactionary in its thinking a good deal of the time.
May 4, 1992

For the Department of Justice to prosecute and to say that it is going to evolve new legal thinking is completely contradictory. It is incredible that we are placed in this position. A great many legal scholars have donated their time. Many have been paid quite reasonably, although certainly not nearly as much as they would have been paid if they were in the private sector, in their own practices. They did the service with the Law Reform Commission because they believed in the concept. They believed in the concept of the Law Reform Commission and the necessary evolution of law in this country.
One comment that is important is that made by Mr. J. J. Camp, who is the president of the Canadian Bar Association. He said, in denouncing the action of the government in doing away with the Law Reform Commission: "I have heard it said that it was too independent. I do not think that is possible". It is a very important statement by a very important man in a very important position.
This country has brought forward some very good legal thinking in the past few years. It has a Charter of Rights and Freedoms which we are about to amend. It has had court decisions based on this Charter of Rights and Freedoms such as the Butler case, which is on obscenity, which has resulted in the overturning of the rape shield law. It has so many other things such a good, sound legal system. We cannot allow this country to be offset by the ridiculous and negative and reactionary thinking of this government.
I call upon this government today to reinstate the Law Reform Commission for the benefit of not only Canadians of the present but for future generations in the very important evolution of our justice system in this country.

Mr. Speaker, I am going to use my time to comment primarily on the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, although the sentiments expressed by this side of the House throughout this debate clearly reflect the wrongheaded thinking of the government in eliminating these advisory committees and councils.
The Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council I know very well because I served on that council for four years as a labour nominee. That council was
Government Orders
made up of no fewer than 15 members and no more than 21 members, in addition to the chairperson. The council was made up of seven members from the employer community, seven members from the labour community and seven members from the non-governmental agency community. Every piece of work that this advisory council did was a consensus document. The labour community was not always satisfied with what appeared in the documents. The employer community was not always satisfied with what appeared in the documents, and certainly the NGO community was not always entirely satisfied.
What did appear in the documents was a reflection of what all three parties were able to agree on. To me, that was very important information for a successive list of ministers of employment and immigration because they were consensus documents.
Therefore, the minister was able to take that documentation and say that it is a pretty clear reflection of where labour, employers and non-governmental agencies are on this issue.
When I served on that advisory council, we met regularly, we worked while we were at the council very hard. Sometimes we used to complain bitterly because we had cold sandwiches and old coffee. The energy level that was brought to the work of the advisory council was, however, quite phenomenal. The staff was excellent, and many of those people were seconded from other departments of the federal government.
We undertook studies which included an annual report to the minister on what the council felt would be the appropriate levels every year on immigration, studies on the difficulties with immigration, studies on the difficulties with backlogs, and on the employment side, a number of very important studies that truly reflected a consensus view.
I would like to briefly run through some of the documents that this group produced as consensus documents.
In 1982 the employment services to natives report to the Minister of Employment and Immigration Canada was a document that was produced at a time when we were in a recession, at a time when many Canadians were hurting in terms of employment but certainly the aboriginal community was suffering even more.

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
This document talked about some of the difficulties and some of the resolutions to that problem.
In 1982 we also did a report for the minister on illegal immigrants. What we discussed in that study was how we felt the minister could best deal with what was becoming an increasing problem for the government; namely, the landing of the illegal immigrants and the subsequent difficulties in processing those people through our existing system.
In 1985 the advisory council did an excellent document on older workers entitled "An Imminent Crisis in the Labour Market". This report was presented to the then minister because again we were coming out of the recession but many workers from the ages of 45 to 55 to 65 had been displaced by the recession and were not likely, even though times were improving, to find themselves back in the work force.
This document provided a blueprint because while there were some safety nets for those workers, there were many workers who tended to fall through those safety nets and were left disenfranchised, if you like, from the world of work.
In 1987 the advisory council produced a document called "Canada's Single-industry Communities: A Proud Determination to Survive". I had the privilege of chairing the committee that did that study on single-industry communities in Canada. That document was a result of endless hours of hard work by representatives on the advisory council from all three groups: employers, unions, and non-governmental agencies, and what we discovered was that we are a country of extractors. Most of the population of the country lives across the 49th parallel and we go in and extract Canada's wealth and resources and then we move out. We shut down whole towns in some cases.
What we were trying to address was how we could ensure that, while the first shovel of ore is one step toward the closing of the mine, for example, we should be addressing ourselves to diversification so that we would not find ourselves shutting down two or three-generation communities and leaving ghost towns in Canada's hinterland.
What we found was that Canada had to make a decision of whether we were going to fly in and fly out
and extract resources or whether we were going to settle the north and central Canada and develop the infrastructure that would make those communities viable with alternate resources and alternate industries.
In 1984 we produced the youth employment report to the Minister of Employment and Immigration Canada, again coming out of the recession and finding ourselves with a lot of young people who had been disenfranchised for a number of years and who now needed to move into the work force. It was on this and how best to facilitate it.
In 1987 the advisory council produced a document called "Tax Policy Implications for Employment". That document was very important to the government in terms of the kinds of things that the government should be aware of when we had large amounts of unemployment, when we had tax implications of not having the full employment policy.
In 1988 "Innovative Approaches to Enterprise Development, a Lever for Employment Growth" was another document presented by the advisory council.
There was also a follow-up document called "Canada's Single-industry Communities: In Search of a New Partnership". That was a follow-up report based on an interdepartmental conference that was attended by people from single-industry communities and by the departments that would be impacted by the study.
In 1988 "The Unemployed Older Worker Phenomenon: A Problem that Will Not Go Away", was a policy note presented to the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
In 1989, there was an Employment and Immigration Canada report called "Regional Unemployment in Canada: A Nation out of Balance". In 1990 "Canada's Full Employment is an Achievable Goal" was a report presented to the minister again by the advisory council. In 1991 "Immigrants and Language Training" was a report presented by the advisory council; and in 1992, Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council did a report on unemployment insurance and part-time work in Canada; and "An Investment in People", a report on Newfoundland that the advisory council did where we travelled in Newfoundland and met with the people about the economy and provided very important recommendations to the minister.
May 4, 1992

To get rid of an advisory council that put forward this kind of consensus documentation seems to be so futile on the part of this government. Maybe it is not so futile. In keeping with this government's record of not listening to anybody about anything, this advisory council produced first-class consensus documents over and over again and I think most of them are sitting on some dusty shelf somewhere. I suspect the ministers much less their departments, have never read them. I think it is despicable. Throwing away this and the other commissions, committees and councils that the government is dismantling is bad thinking. It is bad planning. But I think in view of this government's inability to listen to anybody but itself that we should not be surprised by it.

Mr. Speaker, it is our job as opposition party to criticize. It is also true that the bill tabled by the government is probably one of the worst pieces of legislation I have seen since I came to the House of Commons, both in substance and in terms of the long-term impact on our country.
The government has seen fit to give the boot to the Economic Council of Canada. Granted, the council sometimes submitted reports that were pretty critical of this government and the previous one. But to claim that the Fraser Institute will be able to do the job done by the Economic Council of Canada is simply preposterous.

I cannot over-emphasize the importance of the institutions that are being closed down with one fell swoop by this government, first of all, because they were independent organs of public opinion outside the realm of government that were able to give us guidelines, directions, constructive criticism. They were organizations that could take the politics out of politics. We know the list and we know their contribution. Bernard Wood of the Canadian Institute of International Peace and Security is probably one of the most renowned names internationally in bringing people together, whether it was with the North-South Institute or in the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. What a
Government Orders
long-term deficit the decision to close these institutions will have on public thought outside the levels of government: the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada.
I would like to concentrate my remarks more specifically on an area that has been helpful to me personally in acquitting my responsibilities as a member of Parliament and also I believe has been a national and international leader in terms of taking our country forward. That is the Law Reform Commission. I have here a copy of a study called "Human Dignity and Genetic Heritage". As we speak, there are changes in science that touch the lives of men and women and children across this country over which there is no law, over which there is no jurisprudence.
Several years ago, I introduced a private member's bill in this House which dealt with the issue of whether or not surrogacy should be a for-profit activity in this country. My private member's bill which banned any possibility of renting your womb for profit and any profit-making surrounding the notion of surrogacy did not answer all the questions relating to human conception that we now face as a country, but it was one small step in a plan to have some national strategies to keep ahead of technology.
I introduced that bill several years ago, I believe it was six years ago to be precise. Do you know from whence I drew my most specific scientific data and information? I drew it from the Law Reform Commission of Canada which had the courage and also had the mandate to take these issues one step beyond the political arena.

Whether we like it or not, there are some steps in the legislative process that are not dealt with here in the House of Commons or in the provincial legislatures.

We are still waiting for specific legislation as it relates to the whole explosion of human reproductive technology. We know the difficulties now that have faced the royal commission in even getting a consensus on what we move forward on organizationally and yet-

May 4, 1992
Government Orders

-thanks to the Law Reform Commission of Canada, we have come out miles ahead of all other countries with respect to our ability to manage a very difficult dossier.

In 1983 the Law Reform Commission was examining euthanasia, an issue with which this Parliament has yet to deal.
In 1978 the Law Reform Commission was speaking out on issues relating to sexual offences, issues which we are still grappling with today here in the House of Commons.
In 1984 the Law Reform Commission was speaking out on extraterritorial jurisdiction.
I say shame, shame on the Minister of Justice and shame on the Conservative Party and shame on the Government of Canada that would silence a voice of reason, a voice of vision and a voice of independent, non-partisan critical examination of our laws.
Today the Minister of Justice, in response to legitimate questions posed in this House about the state of the nation, about how it feels to be a young black person in the city of Toronto with no job and no hope, said we did not need a national study because the minister herself had already invoked a specific clause and I quote: "Campbell used a rarely invoked power to request a study on whether the Criminal Code and other federal laws ensure fair treatment and equality of access for aboriginal and multicultural people".
That study will never be published. The study the minister quoted today as the reason for not moving forward on specific government agendas with respect to racial inequalities in this country was shelved along with the other agencies that were put to death by this government.

They are talking about the tremendous savings this will mean and how it will help the deficit. We already know, and the minister herself has said, that what was done by the Law Reform Commission will now be done in her department.
It is cold comfort for Canadians to know, for example, that the Minister of Justice will now be responsible for examining the progress we are making-

-on the Court Challenges Program.

How can Canadians have confidence that the Government of Canada will in an objective way analyze and criticize its own laws? It makes sense that an independent, impartial, extra legislative body can bring forward suggestions, recommendations, and very specific data to force parliamentarians to act.

We as parliamentarians have a very good example of a political dossier unfortunately, because what is happening today in Los Angeles affects us here in the Parliament of Canada. It is absolutely essential for us to have professionals, economists and legal experts, examine where we will be in 20 or 30 years. Do not kill criticism. We must realize that to live in a country like Canada, we need extra-parliamentary institutions to foster human rights and analyse our economic needs.

The government does not have the credibility to do the type of research it claims it is going to do and to silence organizations such as the Science Council of Canada, the Economic Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, and the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. It is a travesty. It is a travesty at a time when Canadians are looking for leadership outside Parliament and at a time when the big questions such as what happens to the whole issue of reproductive technology have not been answered here in this place and they need to be answered for the future of our children.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak on Bill C-63 because of all the irresponsible things that were included in the budget of the Minister of Finance on February 25. To a large extent it was a budget of smoke and mirrors. It was a budget that seemed to provide some minor stimulus and seemed to be doing something where in fact in most cases it really was not making any particular impact on the economy.
May 4, 1992

I think of the proposal for the food processing industry. A week before the budget came out an advisory group had recommended that the government double the capital cost allowance for innovative and expanding facilities for the processing and manufacturing industry. In fact, the government increased the capital cost allowance by 5 per cent.
That industry had had a 50 per cent capital cost write-off only three years before and suddenly it was down to half of that. The advisory committee on competitiveness had recommended it be doubled. In fact, the government increased it by only 5 per cent which was typical of that entire budget. Tb a great extent the budget was a shilly-shallying around of movements that seemed to provide a very minor stimulus. Certainly any of it that really was a stimulus was for later this year or early next year or it seemed to be meeting some kind of political agenda of the government.
When you come to the section of the budget which deals with what the government described as streamlining government, it certainly was not designed to only have a cosmetic affect. It was in one way. That way was that the government was trying to convince the people who are intending to vote for the Reform Party that here was a government that was going to lower the boom on everything in this Government of Canada that had anything to do with science or technology or anything that might be beneficial in the long run. It was really playing that whole mentality that chopping everything in government operations was a good thing to do.
That was the one direction of the government. One was to try to regain some of the support that it has lost to the Reform Party. I understand that there was a poll in Alberta just last week which showed that the Reform Party had something like 69 per cent. Obviously the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, the House leader, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister of Finance are absolutely petrified that they are going to lose their seats in the House of Commons, so they would destroy anything in the Government of Canada.
That is the one dimension that we are very familiar with in this House of Commons. The other dimension
Government Orders
that you have to think about is that these are independent agencies, the Science Council and the Economic Council of Canada, which often criticize the government. This is a government that is at 15 per cent or 20 per cent in the polls and does not need any more criticism than it is already getting.
When the Science Council of Canada criticizes the commitment that is made to R and D and aid in this country the government wants to silence that voice. It is just like a year ago when it chopped the CBC and native newspapers. If anybody criticized the government or its actions, it moved to silence those voices of criticism.
The government is killing off groups like the Science Council or the Economic Council of Canada, agencies that are not doing reports that will have much effect this month, next month or even perhaps this year. Their reports, studies and recommendations are sort of an early warning system of where our society, our science, our economy, our research and development need to be going in the long haul. Clearly, advisory groups like this are invaluable because governments by their very nature have to look at what has to be done today. If there is a crisis in the agriculture sector or a crisis in the manufacturing sector or whatever, governments tend to look at the short-term horizon, certainly not much beyond the next four years or the four year mandate of any particular Parliament.
The Science Council has done tremendous projects in the past. It is easy to just look at its publications to see the kinds of work that it has done. At the current time it is doing a study in agriculture on sustainable agriculture, clearly a very important subject. It is one that is very important because we know that we are facing an incredibly difficult time in agriculture because of the grain wars that have occurred between the United States and the European Community which has driven the price of grains down to the prices that we had in the 1930s. That is a very real and tremendous problem for the agriculture sector both in Ontario and eastern Canada, but especially for those grain producing areas in western Canada. Yet, society is demanding that we produce food with less pesticides, that we do not degra-date the soil, that we maintain the fertility of our industry and of the agricultural sector.

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
That kind of study done by the Science Council of Canada is essential. It has done many studies throughout the years on an unlimited number of topics having to do with international affairs, the impacts of studies in many areas. It has really become the early warning system, not only for this government, but for any government, as to what steps need to be taken in the long haul.
The government, because it is facing a political challenge by the Reform Party, says that 46 agencies have to be chopped. It will certainly impress its supporters in Alberta that it is really chopping down big government, regardless of what the impact is on the Science Council of Canada or the Economic Council of Canada. It sees it as good politics.
This is a travesty. It is a deed that no government should be doing. It limits the future of this government and future governments. It is something that needs to be reversed. It is a bad decision.
I wholeheartedly support the position that has been taken by the Liberal caucus to oppose this bill. It is a mistake, certainly as far as the Science Council, the Economic Council, and the Law Reform Commission are concerned. These are all agencies and bodies that operate in an independent way and make for a better country and a better future for Canada.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I join my colleagues in again rising in outrage at the intolerable steps and the lack of foresight and, as one of my colleagues said, the sheer stupidity of this government in presenting Bill C-63, which reflects the budget priorities to chop six of the most important institutions of democracy in this country.
The 1992 Tory budget has already devastated Canadians and threatens to change the nature of Canada. We saw the government chop the Court Challenges Program, the only program that is available to disadvantaged people and minorities to fight for their rights under our Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
It refused promised funding for the Race Relations Foundation and has not even proclaimed legislation. This week of all weeks we are so conscious of how much that is needed in Canada.
It cut funds for job development and cut transfer payments and assistance for children and families. We can go on and on. Now we have this Bill C-63 which continues the attack on the rights of Canadians and the institutions which are essential for effective, democratic government.
This bill, as we have heard, eliminates major agencies and advisory boards which have been established and have years of sound performance, doing major research, providing expertise and critical analysis of trends in Canada which are essential for sound government policies. These centres of excellence are essential to also provide advice and criticism, yes criticism-of course, that is what bothers this government-in a constructive way that should be used by government to improve legislation and to improve policies that in turn will build a better Canada. All six institutions are very important, not only to government but to the public of Canada to keep us better informed about trends.
Surely this investment is very little for us to be informed about essential and important policy questions and what recommendations are needed for change. The six agencies that are affected and will be done away with by Bill C-63 are the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Law Reform Commission, the Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development and the Science Council of Canada.
I am sure most Canadians, when they think about this, will realize that these are quite unnecessary and devastating cuts. Why is the government doing this? Why is it cutting important, essential institutions to save only a total of $22 million? It could have saved over $50 million by not establishing a phoney Canada-125 private corporation that is not even going to provide funds to communities for July 1 celebrations. Or it could cut the
May 4, 1992

prosperity agenda, a very phoney PR stunt which is costing over $20 million.
But no, it is proceeding with its decision to kill these institutions because it is afraid of what these institutions do. It is afraid of sound research and criticism of government policies. If ever any government needed it, it is this government. Just as it was afraid of advocacy groups, it cut the funding by 50 per cent for many groups in last year's budget.
Many of my colleagues on this side of the House have been commenting on the six institutions. It is well documented what they have done. I must say the debate has been very eloquent and very sincere. This is not political rhetoric. This is deep concern on the part of all of us.
My colleague from Mission-Coquitlam described in detail the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council which she was a member of for a number of years as a labour representative. Previous speakers on the Liberal side spoke eloquently about the Law Reform Commission. I recall the fact mentioned by one member that Canada will join Bangladesh and one other country as the third member of the Commonwealth that has no law reform commission now.
Is this what we want as Canadians? Is this what we will be proud of as Canadians? There are many legal and justice issues that must be monitored by a non-governmental body. We must have recommendations for changes.
I feel, as the member of Parliament for Vancouver East, that we need recommendations that the law commission was preparing on Criminal Code changes, a comprehensive study of the Criminal Code. I would like its advice on what we can do about hate propaganda, for example, and what we can do to counteract racism in Canada.
As the member of Parliament for Vancouver East, where our communities are being seriously damaged by the effects of prostitution related activities, I think we have got to look at the legislation on soliciting, remove it from the Criminal Code and find practical ways to protect neighbourhoods from abuse and to protect women from violence. There have been 25 murders of prostitutes in my riding. This has got to change. I want
Government Orders
some expert advice. It will no longer be available from the Law Reform Commission.
The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security was established in 1984. I want to pay special tribute to Pauline Jewett, then the MP for New Westminster-Coquitlam, who played a very strong role in working for the establishment of this important organization. Its mandate is to increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relating to international peace and security. It was to do this from a Canadian perspective, a Canadian perspective which has proven to be so valuable internationally as well and well respected.
Its emphasis was particularly on arms control, disarmament, defence and conflict resolution. It has contributed to a growing wealth of information and knowledge about these matters and about peacekeeping, and Canada has established an international reputation as a primary contributor to world peace.
Why is this institute being chopped? Does the government think we have achieved eternal international peace, for goodness' sake? I want to say that those of us who were recently at a parliamentary conference in Cameroons, Africa heard constantly day after day from delegates about conflicts in the Middle East, the stalemate in Cyprus, a military coup which occurred in Peru, conflicts in Yugoslavia and the former Soviet Union, as well as in East Timor and many other countries.
Why can the government not afford $5 million to keep this institute going when CSIS was given a $20 million increase and the defence expenditures for the Canadian Armed Forces went up $200 million? This is at a time when the cold war is over and we should be finally bringing our troops home and putting our investment in peace. For that we need the peace institute to advice us and to challenge government. We need it also to challenge the military industrial complex that continues to control expenditures. We have to find ways to create a peace dividend now that we are supposedly and hopefully in a time of peace. This is desperately needed particularly for women and children in developing countries.
I could go on and on. The Economic Council of Canada was not even warned of its demise. Just last week it produced a very important report on educational

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
reforms and government policies that are essential to reduce illiteracy and prepare young people for productive employment.
Our country is surrounded by oceans and yet it is cancelling the very body that is doing research in that area. Surely we need a centre for ocean development with scientific, environmental and economic benefits. The Science Council of Canada is one of the foremost bodies in this country to help us prepare for the future, and it is being chopped.
This government talks about the need for research and development and then it cuts one of the most important bodies that we have to assist in that. We have to make sure that the people of Canada know about this. Surely the government will reconsider. It is a small amount of money and we must have a voice of independent research, advocacy and criticism in order to function as a democratic country, particularly with a Conservative government in power.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to participate in the debate on second reading of Bill C-63 whereby the Government of Canada is terminating a number of agencies which in the past have provided valuable information to public policy makers in this country both at the national level and at the provincial level.
The Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law Reform Commission and the Science Council of Canada, all these institutions provided valuable, reasoned information to public policy makers.
In the preface to my remarks I made reference to the fact that the government was terminating these agencies. It goes beyond the termination of these agencies. For me as a parliamentarian and as one who is concerned about public policy, one must be concerned about the over-all thrust and direction in which the Government of Canada wishes to take the nation as a whole. I will refer to two or perhaps three of these agencies in the few minutes I have.
The Economic Council of Canada is a body which has provided information to Ministers of Finance since it was
put into place some time ago I believe in 1963, if memory serves me correctly. This government has taken it upon itself that it does not wish to hear from Canadians, institutions or agencies of institutions whatever negative things they may wish to say about the government.
If one is a proponent of the government and of the policies of that government, one has a better opportunity in terms of its longevity. On the other hand, if one's sole mandate is not to be political or to suggest a political direction but is to provide reasoned, well-thought-out, well-reflected information on public policy issues of the day, I suggest this government has done what it ought not to have done, which is to terminate the existence of these particular agencies.
The Economic Council of Canada repeatedly provided information to the government of many different political parties of the day, but it has also been able to provide Parliament, academics, labour, business, various interest groups, non-profit interest groups, with information on important public policy issues of the day.
I believe it to be utterly shameful that the Government of Canada would embark upon this type of program when in fact we are in need of those agencies today.
A second agency is the International Centre for Ocean Development. We have heard repeatedly in this House from the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans whose absence is understandable. I am sure that the minister has other important things to do. It is doing away with this agency, the International Centre for Ocean Development, at a time when environmentalists, when people from Fisheries and Oceans, fishermen, and all such interest groups are telling the government that there are serious issues with regard to the fisheries at the present time. I fail to see the rationale for terminating such a useful agency as the International Centre for Ocean Development.
Yes, this particular agency was put in place some time ago, 1991 I believe, at the Commonwealth Heads of State Conference. It was announced in 1991, following the 1982 signing of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. It was incorporated into a non-profit organization in 1983, became a Crown corporation in 1985 and is dependent upon the Government of Canada for its appropriations.

It provides technical assistance, information and training programs to developing countries to approve their management and utilization of ocean resources as a source of food. There is a reciprocal thing there as well. It is not just a matter of giving information or technical support. It is also the beneficiary of expertise and of information on other countries across the world. It employed up to 74 people in the capital city of my province, namely the city of Halifax in the province of Nova Scotia.
Nova Scotian Progressive Conservative members of Parliament have a lot to account for in terms of the sins and the omissions that this government has inflicted on the people of Nova Scotia. This just adds to the list, adds measurably to the list of sins that the Tory government has committed with regard to the people of the province of Nova Scotia.
Why in the name of God would they want to terminate an agency such as the International Centre for Ocean Development when our fisheries, the backbone of the Atlantic economy, are in serious trouble at the present time? I do not say that as a fearmonger. I do not say that to be a politician seeking headlines in the newspapers. I say that as a matter of fact. If one talks to inshore fishermen, those who work in the offshore and those who work in provincial governments, one will quickly recognize the seriousness of the issues which are facing our fishermen and the resources of the sea.
To terminate that agency is stupid politics. It is stupid public policy. It is stupidity by the minister responsible who is bringing forward this bill and particularly the ministers who are aiding and abetting, namely the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and in this particular instance the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
There are other agencies this government is terminating with this particular bill. I refer to the Law Reform Commission of Canada. By profession I am a lawyer. By choice and by practice I am a politician. However I want those who are viewing our proceedings tonight to understand that the Law Reform Commission of Canada carries no brief for the Liberal Party of Canada, no brief for the New Democratic Party of Canada nor for the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada.
Government Orders
In the past it has sometimes demonstrated views to which I do not subscribe. Nevertheless they have been views which have been reasoned, well thought out, and have positive consequential effects for the implementation of public policy in this country. Now we have the government and of course the Minister of Justice going to terminate the Law Reform Commission of Canada as the Minister of Justice has terminated the Court Challenges Program, an essential element giving ordinary Canadians an opportunity to present their legal cases before some of the superior courts of this country.
To terminate the Law Reform Commission again adds injury to insult and shows once again the stupidity of the minister involved. It shows the stupidity of the public policy. It shows the stupidity in the fact that the government wishes to proceed at this time with privatization, in fact doing away with this particular agency.
In the moment that I have remaining I want to say to the government and ministers of the Crown that it is important they hear from a cross-section of Canadians on a variety of issues. Whether that information, those statements or their interventions are positive or negative, they are essential elements the government must take into consideration in the formulation of public policy in the best interests of all Canadians.
I am afraid this government is not only tired and has not only used up its usefulness in this particular Parliament, it is acting in a very stupid manner on behalf of all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, Bill C-63 should not be a surprise to those who have been watching this government closely over the last several years. We can observe an agenda that is totally disinterested in promoting programs that have longterm benefits, benefits that can be measured in terms of quality of life and in terms of future revenue.
Today Canada is the number one country in which to live because of the investments made in human capital decades ago. Canada has a tradition of investing in people. We developed a health care system and an education system that maximized the capacity of people to reach their own potential. It is the access to quality of health care and education and the prosperity generated

Government Orders
by that high quality of education that have made Canada the envy of the world.
It is the foundation of our success that this government has targeted for demolition. This government's Bill C-63, is an extension of its rejection of investments in Canada's human resource, our educated, healthy and secure work force.
Such investments are being rejected because the rewards will not be measured in time for the next election. This is a government that has cut real transfers to post-secondaiy education, transfers for health care and has refused to pay the human and social costs of its own policies.
In the short term, shutting down the institutions and commissions affected by Bill C-63 will have immediate political benefits in the eyes of this government. Money will be saved by the treasury to lower the nominal deficit and the government will not even be liable for the unemployment costs as insured wage earners alone will have to foot that bill through their UI premiums.
Fundamentally, these agencies are being disbanded because they run against the grain of the government's agenda. This government is simply cutting out the tongues of its critics. Let us take the Economic Council of Canada. The mandate of the council is to advise Canada as to how we can "achieve the highest possible levels of employment and efficient production in order that the country may enjoy a high and consistent rate of economic growth and that all Canadians may share in rising living standards".
We all know that high levels of employment are hardly a priority for this government. Price stability is the target and interest rates well above the rate of inflation. This government's agenda sacrifices employment, so why would the government want to hear from organizations whose mandates advocate high levels of employment?
The council's mandate to advise as to how all Canadians can share in rising living standards also puzzles the government. In February last year in the face of record crowds at food banks, this government proposed that new loopholes be put in place to allow the richest Canadians to avoid paying tax on their private trust funds for another generation.
That is this government's idea of sharing; the wealthy keep their private trusts and the poor keep their food banks.
The Science Council of Canada also has a mandate that is bizarre to government theorists. It is mandated to assess scientific and technological resources and advise the ministers as to how to take advantage of Canada's opportunities. This often means spending current dollars for return three, five or ten years down the road and beyond the horizon of this government.
Today, Toshiba rivals all of Canada in research and development spending-a shameful state for a nation of our size. The Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council is there to advise the Minister of Employment and Immigration as to the effects of the department's policies and activities.
It must be really hard on the minister's conscience to have to hear from this body all the time. Worse yet for the minister, this council is supposed to make its opinions and recommendations known to the public. Could anything be worse for the hon. minister?
The Law Reform Commission has a severe timeframe problem for this government. The benefits from the modernization, improvement and reform of legislation, as would be proposed by the commission, will not be realized by 1993. That means spending $4.9 million this year to benefit Canadians later in the decade which is unthinkable to this government.
Bill C-63 is here for two important reasons for the government. First, these commissions are able to gather information, publish expert opinions and publicize objections to government policy. This government is not interested in public awareness. It has financially strangled universities and soon it will be able to silence several of these think-tanks as well.
More dangerous is the fact that this government is not interested in investing in Canada's human capital or in Canada's industry and technology. It has tied its political fate to the size of the current nominal federal deficit. This creates serious policy distortions that have no benefit for the Canadian public that may provide a political resource for this government.
The government has passed the costs previously borne at the federal level on to provinces and municipalities. In the last recession the government was forced to increase
May 4, 1992

transfers by more than 20 per cent in a single year to care for those left unemployed in the economic crisis.
The current government cap on the Canada Assistance Plan offers no benefit to ordinary Canadians but transfers the cost of crippling welfare rates on to municipalities and the provinces. Property taxpayers in my community pay this cost directly on their assessments.
No benefit is derived for Canadians. The cuts in transfers for education on health care are other examples of how the government is not focused on the well-being of Canadians. Bed closings, course cancellations and higher tuition fees reduce the general well-being of the public. These also represent a rejection of the Canadian tradition of investing in people.
This is a government that reaps the revenues from investments made by previous governments but is unwilling to make the same investment in future generations. That is the purpose of these organizations, to plan investments in Canada's future.
Perhaps the political myopia of this government can only be cured by an election.

Mr. Speaker, I suppose we have all heard about the movie The Terminator. It is not a movie any longer. It is not Arnold Schwarzenegger. The terminator lives and is in good health here in the city of Ottawa. This year the terminator is Brian Mulroney.
With this bill terminating these important research agencies, our Ottawa terminator has become the first terminator to shoot himself in the head.
I agree and I believe all parties agree that we have to reduce the cost of government. There is no doubt about that and I am sure there are many things on which we could probably agree. There are areas that we could agree to cut without putting ourselves in a position of no return, or we would not put ourselves in a position in which what we cut would be fatal to our future in a research sense.
Once these agencies are gone, universities, private agencies, are not going to be able to do their job.
There are principally four reasons why I am against this bill. The first reason is that we are cutting important research agencies; shedding, cutting, terminating these
Government Orders
agencies without putting anything in their place. When they are gone, there is nothing else.
A second reason is that these agencies will be gone and will no longer provide a voice of independent critical analysis of this government's actions.

Mr. Speaker, you know as I do that in this House, one party is often blaming another for all the problems in the world. We do not always accept our own responsibilities; we are always blaming others.
But in such a context, it is absolutely essential to have independent agencies that can criticize the government not for partisan gain or for show or to win a Gallup poll but to give Canadian voters an idea of how the government is doing, a critical idea of what the consequences of this government's decisions are.
So just when we need these independent researchers, our government is dismantling forever-and I do mean forever-the agencies that provided this kind of information in the past.
The third reason that I am against this approach of the Conservative government is that it is using radical surgery when it might have merged some groups-it already did that in the past, and I even think that some groups were merged in a single bill. It could have spoken with the managers of these government research agencies to see how their operating costs could have been reduced. But no, it did not want to do that. It wanted radical surgery. Why such radical surgery from the government? Is it because these agencies did a bad job or not a very good job? On the contrary, the government has said many times that the Economic Council of Canada is an excellent organization, that the Law Reform Commission of Canada is an excellent organization. Well, if they are so excellent, why do we have to abolish them? Is it a question of cost? The fourth reason, and the main reason that I oppose this bill which would abolish several research agencies of the federal government is that the $22 million to be saved-government is trying to save, but I am not so sure, since I have already seen savings in the past that were not really savings. This government claims that it will save $22 million from a deficit, or an accumulated

Yes, that's right. One of my Liberal colleagues just told me that it is $400 billion, not $161 billion. I thank the Liberal member for telling me, because they are intimately acquainted with that debt.

Is there anything else the government could have done? I will try and give some figures that are a little more specific than the ones I gave earlier. Mr. Speaker, I really am distressed to have to rise and deal with this bill, particularly in the manner in which it impacts upon my riding of Halifax. I refer, of course, to the cancellation of ICOD, the International Centre for Ocean Development.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in February of this year the government announced in its budget that it would be cutting, eliminating or consolidating 46 Crown agencies, corporations and commissions for a projected savings of $22 million a year.
Bill C-63 in essence is doing that with the first six of these poor corporations to go on the chopping block, the poor sick victims. One of them is the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, another is the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. The others are the Economic Council of Canada, the

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law Reform Commission and the Science Council of Canada.
One wonders whether the government has given a lot of thought to cutting these agencies. One wonders. Some might say that this government really has no idea where the country is going. Over and above that, it does not want to hear where this country is going.
But I will say that this government knows one thing for sure and it is governing all that it is doing over the next little while. That is that it wants to get re-elected in the worst possible way. So now all of its actions are going to be measured in terms of the next election.
What is the one of the first things that can be done at the same time killing two birds with one stone? One is to eliminate a lot of criticism. Independent bodies do not always say nice things about the government and that does not help the prospects of getting re-elected.
Then government members can also say what great managers they were, how they actually saved the Canadian taxpayers some money. So they are going to go back and say to the people: "See how good we are? We have cut costs to the tune of $22 million."
Now let us talk about cutting costs. While cutting off these very important agencies which fulfil a very important role within our country, the government has its own agenda on the side. It is this prosperity agenda, this agenda for competition. A lot of that is fancy brochures and fancy advertising gimmicks again geared solely to convincing the Canadian people that they should vote for government members. The problem is it is not working.
I am going to give you an example from a letter which I happened to read today. It is from a constituent of mine and it says: "Dear Mrs. Marleau: Enclosed you will find not one but three announcements from the Mulroney government announcing a new look to the unemployment cheques." Now, that is three announcements, and the person has enclosed them. "Being unemployed since a Christmas Day fire at the plant where I worked, I find
it unbelievable that the government could waste money on something so frivolous as new cheques."
Can you imagine? At the same time government members are trying to tell the people of Canada that they are good money managers, they are wasting money on all kinds of frivolous things, when the important things are going to be cut out. That is just one example.
I have also received correspondence from other people in my riding complaining about some of the glossy brochures that are being mailed out all over the place at the drop of a hat. There is no end to the amount of money being spent on that kind of propaganda. But when it comes time to fund independent agencies which are of a very good long-term use to this country, then we have no money.
In a hearing on the Economic Council of Canada I asked what the actual costs involved were in winding down an agency such as that.
To begin with, just in terms of the leased location, the Economic Council of Canada has an annual lease on four and a half floors in the Place de Ville building here in town at $813,000 a year. It is going to have to honour that commitment and the lease runs until November 1993.
It will probably move another government office in there, but it will still be faced with that expenditure. There is no saving there. Again, what about computers? What about libraries? This massive infrastructure will just be transferred to another agency and be maintained there, so there really is not that big cost saving in terms of the location at any rate.
The next thing is what the Economic Council of Canada was looking into. Some studies were on the demand of the government. One of them was on the government's impact on competitiveness. This was one project that it had undertaken.
I quote from a list of items that was provided to me: "The purpose of this study is to examine the impact of government on the competitiveness of the Canadian economy. It will assess the effect of major elements of federal, provincial and municipal policies with respect to expenditure, taxation and regulation on the ability of the Canadian economy".
Just before I sat at the finance committee and was given this particular list, there was a directive that we

form a subcommittee of the finance committee to study the theory of regulation within Canada. There was a budget and the whole bit, so now the finance committee instead of the Economic Council of Canada is going to study regulation.
We, of course, work very hard on the finance committee. We will do our very best, but none of us really are experts on regulation. There is another big factor at play in the finance committee and that is that the governing party always controls the end result. If it does not like it, it does not accept it. It does not go forward, so what kind of independent type of authority is it?
It may be somewhat independent if the members of the committee happen to approve. Otherwise, do you know what happens in a committee? If someone in the committee disapproves of what is going on, the government members stand up and walk out. Then quorum is lost and nothing is accomplished.
I want to tell you just one of the things that is happening. I know for a fact that the finance committee is actually asking to hire seven people to help. Why would the finance committee be doing this? Because the Economic Council is no longer doing it.

Of course. What it is doing is unceremoniously dumping an independent advisory council. Where will Canada's applied research be done in the future? Who will do the in-depth, long-term planning? Is it going to be the finance committee that is dominated by the party in power?
Will we be more and more dependent on the applied research that is done in other countries which will not be tested in relation to the realities of Canada? This at a time when the challenge of making wise policy decisions are more and more difficult.
The government says that universities may do some of the work. Some of the private research institutes may do some of the work, but these institutes are very biased. They do not have representatives of union, management or governments and it is essential that all levels work together. These agencies were links, they were bridges to bring these people together. First, they brought together ideas and then they brought people together in the end.

I tell the House that is the greatest loss. One of the lessons that we in Sudbury learned is that you cannot work on your own. You have to bring everyone in together and they all have to co-operate. This bill says that only the party that forms the government has any say in anything that goes on in the future of this country. That is despicable, and we should not stand for it.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the kind of debate we are engaged in tonight is what we get when we extend the rules of the House of Commons to its current absurdity, where the House gets the right to debate something that is as important as this bill, which attempts to dissolve a number of federal agencies, Bill C-63.
The agencies it is proposing to dissolve are six in number. The result of the kind of deal that was made earlier in the day, which permitted us to extend the hours to get on the record, has resulted in a victory for the opposition being able to talk to no one except perhaps the members of public who might inadvertently tune in and their television dials stick and they are stuck with this or nothing.
As we see, there is no interest from the members on the government side. Our persuasive arguments are falling on deaf ears. We are not going to convince any of the government members that they should be voting against this move on the part of the government in its attempt to save, as it says, $22 million, because there are no ears here to listen.
The $22 million that is supposedly going to be saved comes as a result of dissolving six government entities: the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Law Reform Commission of Canada, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the International Centre for Ocean Development and the two that I am going to concentrate my remarks on in my 10 minutes, the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada.
The reason I will concentrate on these two is that they are the two oldest of the agencies being dissolved. The Economic Council of Canada has been in existence for just over 29 years, while the Science Council of Canada has been in existence for 25 years. We are told by the government that it is just a coincidence that each of these agencies has over the last couple of years been headed up by appointees who are female and who I think have been doing an excellent job. The government has

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
decided that these high profile women will lose their agencies and their jobs.
These two agencies that I am worried about cost just over $13 million. The Science Council of Canada has an annual budget of $3.1 million and 29 person-years are allotted to that agency. The Economic Council of Canada, which as I said is 29 years old, has a budget of around $10 million. It was projected this year to have a budget of $10.3 million and would have used 118 person-years. The total budget for the two of them was $13.4 million, employing 147 person-years.
I put those numbers on the record because in my criticism of the government for having done away with this expenditure of money, I wish to spend a little time pointing out other places that the government could have made an equal or better saving of money. It was a decision that was well within the power of this government and the party that now makes up this government to have made.
I go back to 1988 after this government had served its first four years. It had a decision to make toward the end of that first mandate. It had to decide what to do about redistribution and how many seats would exist in the House of Commons. There had been 265 seats in this Chamber. For the 1988 election the decision was made to expand the House of Commons by 30 seats to 295 members. Expansion by 30 seats meant the government did not have to make any decisions in provinces like my own where the number of seats would have had to drop from 14 to 11, or in Manitoba where the same kind of thing might have had to happen.
Instead of facing that awesome responsibility, a hard decision for a political party to make-this is the government after all that claims it is used to making the hard decisions-it decided to duck it, not bother making that decision. It said in the backrooms of the Conservative Party: "Let us just expand the House of Commons by 30 members and then we will not have to tell some of these provinces we are going to have to reduce the amount of people they had representing them".
I am from Saskatchewan. I would have been one of 11 members instead of one of 14, presuming I would have won my seat, but my influence would not have been any less in the chamber of 265. In fact, it would have been slightly better than it is here, one of 14 members from Saskatchewan in a chamber of 295. The saving from that would have been in the neighbourhood of $15 million per year.
In short, it is quite a bit more money than we are saving with getting rid of these two agencies, the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada.
What do the 30 new MPs contribute to the economy of the country? They are entitled to employ 4.5 employees for each new member which means another 135 person-years being applied to the government payrolls; the 135 plus the 30 is 165 person years to sit in the House of Commons and to add to the already heavy pressure for office space around these premises and to supply more people. Was that a good trade? Was it a good trade to give up 147 people at the Science Council and the Economic Council for the 165 political types we get with the added 30 seats that come into the House of Commons? I do not think so.
Do we get objective analysis of government programs from these new 30 members? I am afraid we do not very often. The objective analysis we do get or did get from the Economic Council and from the Science Council is out the window when it comes into the House of Commons.
Did we get objective analysis of science policy with these 30 extra members of Parliament and their staff? Not likely. We only have a modicum of people in this Chamber with a background in science let alone science policy. I think it was a bad trade.
Where was the objective analysis with the 30 new members and all of their staff on economic policy? Well, it has not shown up in most of the debates in this Chamber. There are people with a background in economics and in policy in this Chamber but they cannot in a 10 minute or a 20 minute speech do the kind of work the Economic Council of Canada was able to do; studies which over the years included investigations into the questions of productivity, education, health, agriculture, employment, bankruptcies, mergers and acquisitions, the constitutional debate, and even retraining.
May 4, 1992

It was very efficient in its operations, using only 12 per cent of the money allocated to it for administrative purposes. Sixty-five per cent of its budget actually went into the research and policy analysis, and another 23 per cent of its remaining budget went into public information and consultations so the discoveries of the agency could be disseminated to the general public. A very efficient use of funds which this government has now taken away, a 29 year record of good service to the nation and this government is now throwing that away.
I say a trade-off for a political decision it could not bring itself to make back in 1988.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this debate concerns the abolition of a series of government agencies that frankly have served Canada extremely well.
I am disappointed that the government has seen fit to introduce this bill as a follow-up to its budget announcement. It was wrong-headed. I think every member on this side of the House thinks it is wrong-headed. I am sure that all the members on the other side think it is wrong headed and that is why they have all departed.
I find it distressing that on a bill of this importance, a bill that arises out of the budget, that I speak to a House that has only Liberal and New Democratic Party members in it. It is a shame, a disgrace that there are not members of the other political party in this House present to participate in this debate and to listen to the comments of the members of the opposition which condemn this particular bill.
Recently I had occasion to travel to South Africa with two colleagues from this House who sit on the other side, the hon. member for Hastings-Frontenac-Lennox and Addington and the hon. member for London- Middlesex, on a trip sponsored by the Government of South Africa. The three of us were travelling together. One of the interviews we had in the course of our visit to that country was with a member of the South African Law Reform Commission. It was interesting to note that as our meeting got under way, the first thing this gentleman said was how impressed he was with the work of the Canadian Law Reform Commission. He said that the research that was done by that commission was some of the best they ever received. Of course, they had a regular exchange of documentation with the Canadian
Government Orders
Law Reform Commission. He spoke in extremely laudatory terms of its excellent work and of its excellent reputation in South Africa.
I turned to him and said: "Do you realize that in the budget released a few days before our trip the Law Reform Commission in Canada is to be abolished". He was shocked. I can only say that my two colleagues, who of course support the government at every turn, started to look as though they were suffering from severe mortification of the flesh because they were really grim-faced and said: "Wouldn't you know you would bring that up". They did not seem very pleased about it, although it provoked some amusement on my part at being able to mention it in front of them. It certainly caused them acute embarrassment and well it should have.
They should be here today debating this bill. They should be telling the Prime Minister and the Minister of Finance what they think of this policy because the policy is a rotten one. It is not in the best interest of Canada or of Canadians. Not that the best interest of Canadians has ever been a concern of this government. I would not want to make it appear that I am suggesting that it is. It has not been. Canadians want an election to get rid of this government, the sooner the better.
There are three particular bodies that I want to mention in this bill. It is fair to consider one other thing and that is the financial aspect of it. The government said that by eliminating these 46 agencies it listed in the budget speech, it would save $22 million. Twenty-two million dollars and it would get rid of 46 different agencies. It is not much of a saving because after all, the budget of the Economic Council of Canada alone was about $10 million. Somewhere in this, there is something going on. Too many of the jobs are being fudged off somewhere else. They are probably being moved to ministers' offices.
Agency elimination is supposedly to save $22 million. This bill that we are debating today only deals with six agencies. So this bill is not the one that saves $22 million. It saves considerably less than $22 million because there are 40 other agencies to be scrapped that are not dealt with in this bill. In fact, by this bill, we are not saving very much money for the government at all. Frankly this morning I heard the hon. member for Windsor West suggest that the government could save this money better if it cut its advertising program with its wasteful

May 4, 1992
Government Orders
and extravagant expenditure as detailed in one small area by the hon. member for Sudbury a moment ago.
The savings are minuscule. The cost to Canadians in terms of lost opportunity, lost advice, lost attempts to bring together the various elements that participate in these agencies is going to be much greater than the $22 million, let alone the smaller amount that was covered as a result of this particular bill.
The Economic Council of Canada was established in 1963. I note in debates of that time that the Right Hon. Lester Pearson was the mover of the resolution that had to be moved in advance of the introduction of the bill. That procedure has been abolished but the fact is that he moved it first.
I was interested, as I looked through the debate in 1963, to find a speech by the then hon. member for Saint-Maurice-Lafleche, none other than the Leader of the Opposition in the House today. It was clearly one of his early speeches in the House on July 15, 1963 because he, after all, was first elected in the election in May of that year. I would like to quote something he said in his speech because the words are instructive and a clear indication of the way the Economic Council has served the interests of Canadians.

I quote from page 2216 of the Debates of the House for July 15, 1963:
In a word, this economic council should not be content to be a propaganda machine for the government, as was so often the case for similar bodies in the past, but it should be a living impartial and courageous body whose qualifications and work will give the nation confidence in it and which thus will be able to play the part we have a right to expect from it, namely draw up a master plan for our economy to ensure the well-being of the Canadian people.

The council has fulfilled that role in Canada. It did not become a mouthpiece or an organ for the government. It has been critical of government. It has suggested ways in which the government could improve its economic performance. It has done it consistently for a veiy long time to both Liberal and Conservative governments.
Finally, it is this government that has said: "We do not want to hear this advice because the advice, frankly, is critical of the disastrous policies that we have been pursuing in this country". That is the attitude it takes and so it has decided to close the council down.
The council has been served by many very distinguished Canadians, many of them from my own community. Dr. David Slater was a member of the council for many years. Dr. Deutsch from Queen's University, subsequently its principal, was, if not the first, the second head of the Economic Council. In its early days the council was particularly successful. Its annual review was an event in Ottawa. It was looked forward to as something extremely important and it received considerable press attention.
In latter years, with the proliferation of reports and the diversity of the reports that the Economic Council has produced, the publicity has been less. Nevertheless, the reports have had a significant impact. They have provided food for thought. They have provided interesting and useful advice to the government which, in the case of this particular government, it has chosen to ignore.
With respect to the Science Council of Canada, it is clear that the council has been providing advice that the government does not want to hear. It has undertaken a study of research and development in Canada among private industries and it is, I am sure, going to become apparent as those results are released that private industry in Canada has done something significant in that regard. It is the government that has failed Canadians in its commitment to research and development.
We keep hearing about the Prime Minister's desire to improve the climate for research and development in Canada. He keeps talking about the wonderful programs his government has implemented but most of the programs have been cuts and redevelopment of moneys that were already in the programs with a fancy new label, with a fancy new advertising gimmick, such as we had today on child care programs. There is a beautiful colour brochure produced advertising the fact that the government is undertaking something, but all it is doing is carrying on with what it was doing before with cuts. By putting a lot of gloss on it and publishing a lot more brochures and distributing them widely in the country, you somehow create the impression that you are doing something instead of doing less than nothing. That is exactly what the government has been doing consistently since it took office. I tell you, Mr. Speaker, the cuts have been devastating for Canadians. Canadians know when a cut is a cut. They are not bamboozled by this kind of
May 4, 1992

Government Orders
advertising technique and they are not bamboozled by this government when it says it is going to save all this money by introducing this kind of bill.
Canadians will be the losers as the result of the passing of this legislation. Canadians will not win and this government knows it and it should withdraw the bill.
